ARTICLE IV. - TRUCK ROUTES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2191, §§ 1-7, adopted June 18, 2007, amended Art. IV in its entirety and enacted similar provisions as set out herein. The former Art. IV derived from Ord. No. 211, §§ 1-3, adopted July 6, 1971. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 9-86. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given in this section. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    City means the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama. 
    Deviating truck means a truck which leaves and departs from a truck route while traveling inside the city. 
    Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
    Truck means any vehicle and/or trailer designed or operated for the transportation of property which has more than two axles. 
    Truck route means a way over certain streets, as designated herein, over and along which trucks coming into, traveling in and going out of the city must operate. 
Ord. No. 2191, § 1, 6-18-07; Ord. No. 2303, § 1, 11-23-09) 
Sec. 9-87. - Application of regulation. 
    All trucks within the city shall be operated only over and along the truck routes established and on the other designated streets over which truck travel is permitted. 
    Exceptions. This section shall not prohibit: 
(1)  Operation on street of destination. The operation of trucks upon any street where necessary to the conduct of business at a destination point, provided streets upon which such traffic is permitted are used until reaching the intersection nearest the destination point. 
(2)  Emergency vehicles. The operation of emergency vehicles upon any street in the city. 
(3)  Public utilities. The operation of trucks owned or operated by the city, public utilities, any contractor or material man, while engaged in the repair, maintenance or construction of streets, street improvements sidewalks, or utilities within the city. 
(4)  Detoured trucks. The operation of trucks upon any officially established detour in any case where such truck could lawfully be operated upon the street for which such detour is established. 
(5)  Sanitation trucks. The operation of trucks used for collection of residential garbage, recyclables and/or debris as contracted by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2191, §§ 2, 3, 6-18-07; Ord. No. 2303, §§ 2, 3, 11-23-09) 
Sec. 9-88. - Truck traffic in the city. 
(a)  Outside origin. 
(1)  One inside destination point. All trucks entering the city for a destination point in the city shall proceed only over an established truck route and shall deviate only at the intersection with the street, upon which such traffic is permitted, nearest to the destination point. Upon leaving the destination point, a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by the shortest permissible route. 
(2)  Multiple inside destination points. All trucks entering the city for multiple destination points shall proceed only over established truck routes and shall deviate only at the intersection with the street, upon which such traffic is permitted, nearest to the first destination point. Upon leaving the first destination point a deviating truck shall proceed to other destination points by the shortest direction and only over streets upon which such traffic is permitted. Upon leaving the last destination point, a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by the shortest permissible route. 
(b)  Inside origin. 
(1)  Outside destination point. All trucks on a trip originating in the city, and traveling in the city for a destination point outside the city shall proceed by the shortest direction over streets on which such traffic is permitted to a truck route as herein established. 
(2)  Inside destination points. All trucks on a trip originating in the city, and traveling in the city for destination points in the city shall proceed only over truck routes or streets upon which such traffic is permitted intersecting with truck routes nearest the destination point. 
(Ord. No. 2191, § 5, 6-18-07; Ord. No. 2303, § 6, 11-23-09) 
Sec. 9-89. - Enforcement. 
    The chief of police of the city shall cause all truck routes to be clearly sign-posted to give notice that this section is in effect. 
(Ord. No. 2191, § 6, 6-18-a07) 
Sec. 9-90. - Penalties. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided for in section 1-5 of the Code of Ordinances for the City of Vestavia Hills, Repub. 2002. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(Ord. No. 2191, § 7, 6-18-07) 
Secs. 9-91-9-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REGULATIONS ON CERTAIN STREETS 

Sec. 9-96. - Truck routes established. 
    There are hereby established within the city the following "truck routes": 
(1)  Green Springs Highway (aka Columbiana Road); 
(2)  U.S. Highway 31 (aka Montgomery Highway), from the southern City limits to the northern City limits; 
(3)  Acton Road; 
(4)  Cahaba River Road; 
(5)  Cahaba Heights Road; 
(6)  Crosshaven Drive; 
(7)  U.S. Highway 280; and 
(8)  Green Valley Road. 
(Ord. No. 2191, § 4, 6-18-07; Ord. No. 2303, § 4, 11-23-09) 
Sec. 9-97. - Trucks prohibited. 
    Trucks are prohibited on all residential municipal streets unless posted as a truck route or a local delivery as defined in section 9-88. 
(1)  Trucks with more than two axles and/or a maximum gross weight of 10,000 pounds or more are prohibited on residential municipal streets. 
(2)  Signage will be posted as deemed necessary by the chief of police to indicate "Local Delivery Only" or maximum of two axles and/or a maximum gross weight of 10,000 pounds or more. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 5, 11-23-09) 
Secs. 9-98-9-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 9-111. - Twenty-four hour parking. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park trailers, mobile homes, unserviceable automobiles and vehicles, campers or boats on public streets or public street rights-of-way within the corporate limits of the city for a period of time beyond 24 hours. 
(Ord. No. 347, § 1, 6-7-76) 
Sec. 9-112. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2304, § 1, adopted Nov. 23, 2009, repealed § 9-112 in its entirety, which pertained to one-hour parking-definition and derived from Ord. No. 189, § 2, adopted Oct. 5, 1970. 
Sec. 9-113. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2304, § 1, adopted Nov. 23, 2009, repealed § 9-113 in its entirety, which pertained to same-vehicles, locations affected and derived from Ord. No. 189, § 1, adopted Oct. 5, 1970. 
Sec. 9-114. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2305, § 1, adopted Nov. 23, 2009, repealed § 9-114 in its entirety, which pertained to parking prohibited on Vestavia Manor Drive between Post Oak Road and Old Orchard Road at certain times and derived from Ord. No. 953, §§ 1-5, adopted March 24, 1988. 
Sec. 9-114.1. - Parking restrictions on Highway 31 between Canyon Road and Old Creek Trail. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section, the following terms shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Motor vehicle shall mean every vehicle which is self-propelled and every vehicle which is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires, but not operated upon rails. 
(2)  Persons shall mean any person, firm, corporation or association. 
(b)  Prohibitions. The following shall be prohibited uses of a street within the corporate limits of the City of Vestavia Hills: 
Unauthorized parking. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave, or cause to be parked or left, any motor vehicle on Old Highway 31 or the Old Highway 31 right-of-way located between Canyon Road and Old Creek Trail running east and west parallel to Highway 31 for any period of time in excess of eight consecutive hours. 
(c)  Presumption of guilt. The presence of an unattended motor vehicle (as defined in subsection (a)(1) above) parked (as defined in subsection (b) above) on Old Highway 31 or the Old Highway 31 right-of-way between Canyon Road and Old Creek Trail for any period of time exceeding eight consecutive hours or one who is not the owner of, or in control of, such motor vehicle parked or left, or caused to be parked or left, said motor vehicle on above described section of right-of-way for any period of time exceeding eight consecutive hours, such motor vehicle shall raise a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such motor vehicle parked or left, or caused to be parked or left and the burden of proof shall be upon the registered owner thereof to show otherwise. 
(d)  Special events. The mayor of the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama, may grant temporary permission to use the above described right-of-way during any specified hours when parking is normally limited by posting temporary signs or posters to that effect. The person in charge shall notify the police department of any such temporary permission. 
(e)  Penalty. Any person, entity or corporation found to be in violation of subsection (b) of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not less than $25.00 nor more than 500.00 and/or may be imprisoned or sentenced to hard labor for the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama, or its delegate for a period not exceeding six months, at the discretion of the court trying the case. 
(Ord. No. 1694, §§ 1-5, 6-16-97) 
Sec. 9-115. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2306, § 1, adopted Nov. 23, 2009, repealed § 9-115 in its entirety, which pertained to stop signs-placement and installation and derived from Ord. No. 832, §§ 1-5, adopted April 21, 1986. 
Sec. 9-116. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2307, § 1, adopted Nov. 23, 2009, repealed § 9-116 in its entirety, which pertained to same-Canyon Road and Vesta View Lane and derived from Ord. No. 831, §§ I-IV, adopted April 21, 1986. 
Secs. 9-117-9-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PUBLIC PARKING AREAS 

Sec. 9-121. - Definition. 
    For the purpose of this division, any area (even though privately owned) provided in connection with a shopping center or other business establishment for the access, movement and parking of motor vehicles and which is open to the public generally for such use shall be termed a "public parking area." 
(Ord. No. 454, § 1, 11-20-78; Ord. No. 1197, § 1, 1-7-91) 
Sec. 9-122. - Fire lanes. 
(a)  The chief of the fire department is hereby authorized to establish, or cause to be established, fire lanes in any "public parking area" for the purpose of providing adequate access for emergency vehicles and equipment to and from all store buildings and structures adjacent to or served by such parking area. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle in a fire lane which has been established and clearly marked by painting the curb yellow and by posting signs designating the same as a fire lane. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 2, 11-20-78; Ord. No. 1197, § 2, 1-7-91) 
Sec. 9-123. - Driveways. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in a roadway or lane designated by appropriate markings or arrows for ingress or egress into, from or through any "public parking area." 
(Ord. No. 454, § 3, 11-20-78; Ord. No. 1197, § 3, 1-7-91) 
Sec. 9-124. - Presumption. 
    The presence of an unattended automobile or other motor vehicle at any of the places designated as a fire lane for egress or ingress to a "public parking area," which lanes are designated by appropriate signs, painting, private markers or arrows, unless it is known that a person who is not the owner of such vehicle has left it at such location, shall raise a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of the automobile or other motor vehicle parked or left or caused to be parked or left the automobile or other vehicle on such fire lanes or other designated prohibited lanes, and the burden of proof shall be upon the registered owner to show otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 4, 11-20-78; Ord. No. 1197, § 4, 1-7-91) 
Sec. 9-125. - Parking on premises of another after having been warned not to do so. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave or cause to be parked or left any automobile or other motor vehicle on the premises of another after having been warned not to do so by word of mouth or sign or otherwise; provided, that this section shall not apply to employees of the city in the discharge of their official duties. 
(b)  The presence of an unattended automobile or other motor vehicle on the premises of one who is not the owner or in control of the automobile or other motor vehicle shall raise a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of the automobile or other motor vehicle parked or left or caused to be parked or left the automobile or other motor vehicle on the premises, and the burden of proof shall be upon the registered owner to show otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 1197, § 5, 1-7-91) 
Sec. 9-126. - Penalty. 
    A person, firm, corporation or other entity violating any of the provisions of this ordinance shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall be fined an amount not to exceed $25.00 as provided in Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-9. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 5, 11-20-78; Ord. No. 1197, § 6, 1-7-91) 
Secs. 9-127-9-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ABANDONED VEHICLES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Solid waste, Ch. 14. 
State Law reference- Abandoned motor vehicles, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-13-1 et seq. 

Sec. 9-136. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation of this division: 
    Person means any person, firm, partnership, corporation, association, company, or organization, of any kind. 
    Property means any real property within the city or police jurisdiction which is not a street or highway. 
    Street or highway means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
    Vehicle means a machine propelled by power other than human power designed to travel along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners, or slides, and transport persons or property or pull machinery and shall include, without limitation, automobile, truck trailer, motorcycle, tractor, buggy and wagon. 
(Ord. No. 357, § 1, 12-6-76; Ord. No. 2308, § 1, 11-23-09) 
Sec. 9-137. - Abandonment of vehicles. 
    No person shall abandon any vehicle within the city of the police jurisdiction. It shall be presumed that any vehicle which has been left at any place on a street or highway within the city for a period of 48 hours consecutively is an abandoned vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 357, § 2, 12-6-76; Ord. No. 2308, § 2, 11-23-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2308, § 2, adopted Nov. 23, 2009, changed the title of § 9-137 from "Prohibited" to "Abandonment of vehicles." This historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Sec. 9-138. - Leaving of wrecked, nonoperating vehicle on street. 
    No person shall leave any partially dismantled, non-operating, wrecked, or junked vehicle on any street or highway within the city. 
(Ord. No. 357, § 3, 12-6-76; Ord. No. 2308, § 3, 11-23-09) 
Sec. 9-139. - Disposition of wrecked or discarded vehicles. 
    No person in charge or control of any property within the city, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee or otherwise, shall allow any partially dismantled, nonoperating, wrecked, junked or discarded vehicle to remain on such property longer than 72 hours; and no person shall leave any such vehicle on any property within the city for a longer time than 72 hours; except that this division shall not apply with regard to a vehicle in an enclosed building; a vehicle on the premises of a business enterprise operated in a lawful place and manner, when necessary to the operation of such business enterprise; or a vehicle in an appropriate storage place or depository maintained in a lawful place and manner by the city. 
(Ord. No. 357, § 4, 12-6-76) 
Sec. 9-140. - Impounding. 
    The chief of police, or any member of his department designated by him, is hereby authorized to remove or have removed any vehicle left at any street, highway, right-of-way within the city which reasonably appears to be in violation of this division or lost, stolen, or unclaimed. Any vehicle so removed shall be stored in a suitable place provided by the city. For each removed vehicle, a permanent record giving the vehicle description, date of removal, place where found and impound location shall be kept by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 357, § 5, 12-6-76; Ord. No. 2308, § 4, 11-23-09) 
Sec. 9-141. - Sale. 
    At least every six months, the chief of police shall sell at public auction to the highest bidder for cash, the vehicle or vehicles authorized in this division to be removed and taken up and which shall have been taken up and stored for a period of three months or more, the sales to be made after notice of the time and place therefor shall have first been given by publication once a week for two successive weeks and by posting such notice in a conspicuous place at the city hall. The first posting of the notice shall be at least 20 days before the sale. Each vehicle shall be sold separately and a notation in the storage book shall be made of the amount received for each vehicle. The person making the sale shall have the right to reject any and all bids if the amount bid is unreasonably low and shall have the right to continue the sale from time to time if no bidders are present. After deduction and payment of all expenses incurred in the removal, taking up, storing, maintaining and selling of the vehicle or vehicles, the balance if any shall be paid into the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 357, § 6, 12-6-76) 
Sec. 9-142. - Redemption. 
    The owner of any vehicle impounded as herein provided may redeem the same at any time prior to its sale by paying the reasonable expense of taking the vehicle in charge, including removal, impoundment, maintenance and storage. 
(Ord. No. 357, § 7, 12-6-76; Ord. No. 2308, § 5, 11-23-09) 
Secs. 9-143-9-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - UNAUTHORIZED PARKING ON PRIVATE PREMISES 

Sec. 9-151. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business parking lot shall mean any privately owned parking lot providing free parking during business hours adjacent to any store, retail establishment, office building, commercial building or industrial building. 
    Motor vehicle shall mean every vehicle which is self-propelled and every vehicle which is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires, but not operated upon rails. 
    Person shall mean any person, firm, corporation or association. 
(Ord. No. 1404, § 1, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 9-152. - Prohibitions. 
    The following shall be prohibited uses of a business parking lot: 
(1)  Unauthorized parking. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave, or cause to be parked or left, any motor vehicle, on premises of another, including specifically a business parking lot, after being warned not to do so by word of mouth, or by sign or otherwise; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to officers or employees of the city in and about the discharge of their official duties. 
(2)  Trespassing after hours. No person shall enter or stay on any business parking lot at any time that staying or entering the lot is prohibited by the owner, as shown by a sign located upon a business parking lot, and no person shall place or leave any vehicle on any business parking lot at any such prohibited time. 
(3)  Other unauthorized parking. No person shall enter or stay on any business parking lot or park, permit to be parked, place or leave any motor vehicle, or encourage another person to park or permit to be parked, place or leave any motor vehicle, at any time in, on, or about any business parking lot unless such person shall be a customer, invitee, or licensee of the owner except by the express permission of the owner. 
(Ord. No. 1404, § 2, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 9-153. - Presumption of guilt. 
    The presence of an unattended motor vehicle, as defined in section 9-151 above, on the premises (including a business parking lot) of one who is not the owner of, or in control of, such motor vehicle shall raise a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such motor vehicle parked or left, or caused to be parked or left, said motor vehicle on said premises (including a business parking lot), and the burden of proof shall be upon the registered owner thereof to show otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 1404, § 3, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 9-154. - Signs. 
    The prohibitions set out in section 9-152 of this division shall be in effect at any business parking lot where the owner has posted a sign or signs clearly stating the prohibition. Signs must be placed so that they can be seen either at all entrances to the lot or at prominent locations. Each sign may contain substantially the following language: 
CUSTOMER PARKING ONLY 
NO PARKING OR TRESPASSING BETWEEN 
HOURS OF ____________ AND ____________ 
Unauthorized Parking Subject to 
Vestavia Hills Ordinance No. 1404 
(Ord. No. 1404, § 4, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 9-155. - Exceptions. 
    The following uses of a business parking lot shall not be a violation of this division: 
(1)  Temporary entrance to a business parking lot in an emergency or to avoid an accident. 
(2)  Entrance by a police officer or officers in the course of duty. 
(3)  Entrance by fire, ambulance, and other emergency personnel and equipment, in the course of duty. 
(4)  Entrance by an owner, tenant, or authorized employee of any owner or tenant of any establishment served by the parking lot. 
(5)  Entrance by any city inspector in the course of duty. 
(Ord. No. 1404, § 5, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 9-156. - Special events. 
    The owner of any business parking lot may grant temporary permission to use the lot during any specified hours when parking or trespassing is normally prohibited, by posting temporary signs or posters to that effect. The owner or person in charge shall notify the police department of any such temporary permission. 
(Ord. No. 1404, § 6, 10-4-93) 
Secs. 9-157-9-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - HANDICAPPED PARKING 

Sec. 9-161. - "Handicapped individual" defined. 
    For purposes of this division, the term "handicapped individual" means any person having a permanent mental or physical handicap, which limits mobility to the extent that the individual would have difficulty safely walking along a distance of 50 feet or more. 
(Ord. No. 720, § 1, 7-16-84; Ord. No. 976, § 1, 6-20-88) 
Sec. 9-162. - Distinctive decal authorized; medical proof, fees, rules, etc. 
    Beginning with the implementation of the staggered system of motor vehicle license plate registration, any person who submits to the judge of probate, license commissioner or other issuing authority medical proof satisfactory to the commissioner of revenue that he or she is a handicapped individual, as herein defined, shall be issued a distinctive license plate decal and a special identification placard displaying the international symbol of access thereby designating the driver of the vehicle or the passenger as being a handicapped person. The distinctive license decals and placards provided herein shall be prepared by the commissioner of revenue and shall be issued in the same manner as motor vehicle license plates and the issuing officers shall be entitled to their regular fees for such services. 
(Ord. No. 976, § 2, 6-20-88) 
Sec. 9-163. - Unlimited parking periods; exceptions. 
    The handicapped individuals to whom these distinctive license decals and placards are issued shall be allowed to park for unlimited periods in parking zones designated for handicapped persons. Provided, however, that such handicapped persons shall pay parking fees the same as any other person. The provisions of this section shall not apply to zones where stopping, standing or parking is prohibited to all vehicles or which are reserved for special types of vehicles, nor will these provisions apply where there is a local ordinance prohibiting parking during heavy traffic periods during morning, afternoon or evening rush hours, or where parking would clearly present a traffic hazard. 
(Ord. No. 976, § 3, 6-20-88) 
Sec. 9-164. - Penalty for false representations or misuse of privileges. 
    Any person who is not a handicapped individual, as herein defined, and who willfully or falsely represents himself or herself as a handicapped person to obtain the distinctive decals and placards prescribed by this division or misuses or abuses the parking privilege protected by this division, or owns a vehicle bearing the distinctive license decals and is not entitled to do so under the provisions of this division, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punishable by a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 976, § 4, 6-20-88) 
Sec. 9-165. - Unauthorized use of handicapped parking place. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person who does not have a distinctive handicapped decal, as provided in section 9-162, to park a motor vehicle in a parking place designated for the handicapped at any place of public accommodation, amusement or resort or any other place to which the general public is invited, even though located on private property, and upon conviction thereof, shall be fined $100.00 per occurrence. Such fines shall be paid in the same manner as other municipal fines for driving violations. 
(b)  Any authorized municipal, county or state law enforcement officer may go onto private property to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall be held in pari materia with all other provisions of law related to illegal handicapped parking violations; provided, however, that all laws or parts of laws which conflict with the provisions of this section are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 720, § 6, 7-16-84; Ord. No. 976, § 5, 6-20-88) 
Sec. 9-166. - Designation of handicapped parking spaces. 
    Handicapped parking places shall be designated as reserved for the handicapped by the following symbols of accessibility: 
(1)  Posting signs visible from such stalls or spaces. The sign shall be the international symbol of accessibility consisting of a profile view of a stylized wheelchair with occupant in white on a blue background; and 
(2)  Such stalls or spaces shall be designated with blue paint and the international symbol of accessibility shall also be painted in said space. 
(Ord. No. 720, § 2, 7-16-84; Ord. No. 976, § 6, 6-20-88) 
Sec. 9-167. - Persons authorized to designate handicapped parking spaces. 
    The city engineer and the chief of police of the city are the individuals authorized to designate the parking spaces for handicapped individuals. 
(Ord. No. 976, § 7, 6-20-88) 
Sec. 9-168. - Public property. 
    The chief of police and city engineer are hereby authorized to designate not more than one marked parking space within any city block for the exclusive parking of motor vehicles of physically handicapped persons. 
(Ord. No. 720, § 3, 7-16-84; Ord. No. 976, § 8, 6-20-88) 
Sec. 9-169. - Private property. 
    The chief of police and city engineer, in addition to the above provisions, are also authorized to designate certain parking spaces in parking decks, or privately owned parking lots, and authorize such spaces to be posted as parking for handicapped persons under the provisions of this section. The parking spaces so designated, in parking decks or privately owned parking lots, shall be subject to the same provisions, regulations and penalties as provided in this section. 
(Ord. No. 720, § 4, 7-16-84; Ord. No. 976, § 9, 6-20-88) 
Sec. 9-170. - Minimum number of accessible spaces required for handicapped persons. 
    The minimum number of accessible spaces required for handicapped persons is set forth below. 
Total Parking in Lot Required Minimum Number 
of Accessible Spaces   1 to 25 1   26 to 50 2   51 to 75 3   76 to 100 4   101 to 150 5   151 to 200 6   201 to 300 7   301 to 400 8   401 to 500 9   501 to 1000 *   1001 and over **  
 * Two percent of total. 
** Twenty plus one for each 100 over 1,000. 
(Ord. No. 976, § 10, 6-20-88) 
Sec. 9-171. - Location. 
    Parking spaces for disabled people and accessible loading zones that serve a particular building shall be the spaces or zones located closest to the nearest accessible entrance on an accessible route. In separate parking structures or lots that do not serve a particular building, parking spaces for disabled people shall be located on the shortest possible circulation route to an accessible pedestrian entrance of the parking facility. 
(Ord. No. 976, § 11, 6-20-88) 
Sec. 9-172. - Size of parking spaces. 
    Parking spaces for disabled people shall be at least 96 inches (2,440 millimeters) wide and shall have an adjacent access aisle 60 inches (1,525 millimeters) wide minimum (see figure below). 
Size of Parking Spaces 
    Two accessible parking spaces may share a common access aisle. Parked vehicle overhangs shall not reduce the clear width of an accessible circulation route. Parking space and access aisles shall be level with surface slopes not exceeding 1:50 in all directions. 
    Exception. If accessible parking spaces for vans designed for handicapped persons are provided, each should have an adjacent access aisle at least 96 inches (2,440 millimeters) wide. 
(Ord. No. 976, § 12, 6-20-88) 
Sec. 9-173. - Handicapped individuals permitted to park in designated places. 
    Any handicapped person, who, heretofore or hereafter, has qualified as a handicapped persons under the provisions of section 9-161 (Act No. 81-695 of the 1981 Legislature of Alabama), is authorized to use any parking space described and designated in section 9-162 hereof for the parking of a motor vehicle by such handicapped person, provided the motor vehicle parked by said handicapped person in such parking space displays the handicap placard, license plate, decal and otherwise meets the requirements of section 9-161 (Act No. 81-695 of the 1981 Legislature of Alabama). 
(Ord. No. 720, § 5, 7-16-84; Ord. No. 976, § 13, 6-20-88) 
Sec. 9-174. - Prima facie evidence. 
    In any prosecution for the violation of any provision of this division, relating to the operation or parking of vehicles, it shall be prima facie evidence that the owner of such vehicle was operating the same at the time of such alleged violation (i.e. in case of parking in a handicapped place as defined in section 9-162 hereof, that the owner parked the vehicle and caused it to be parked in violation of this section). 
(Ord. No. 720, § 7, 7-16-84; Ord. No. 976, § 14, 6-20-88) 
Secs. 9-175-9-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - REMOVAL OF VEHICLES, TRAILERS OR SEMI-TRAILERS ON PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2314, §§ 1, 2, adopted Nov. 23, 2009, added provisions to the Code but did not specify manner of inclusion. Therefore, at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been included as §§ 9-181, 9-182. 

Sec. 9-181. - [Removal; impoundment.] 
    Whenever a police officer finds a motor vehicle, trailer, or semi-trailer as defined in Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-1-1, parked or left standing upon a public street or public way in such a position or under such circumstances as to obstruct the normal movement of traffic or when an officer determines the vehicle poses a traffic hazard, such officer is authorized to have the vehicle removed to and impounded at the wrecker service designated by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2314, § 1, 11-23-09) 
Sec. 9-182. - [Authority.] 
    Any police officer is hereby authorized to remove or cause any vehicle found upon a public street or way to be removed to and impounded at the wrecker service designated by the city when: 
(1)  Report has been made that such vehicle has been stolen or taken without the consent of the owner; 
(2)  The person or persons in charge of such vehicle are unable to provide for its custody or removal; 
(3)  When the person driving or in control of such vehicle is arrested for an alleged offense; or 
(4)  When a vehicle has been left on or adjacent to any public street or way that the police officer determines impedes the safe ingress/egress of vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 2314, § 2, 11-23-09) 
Secs. 9-183-9-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SALES OF MOTOR VEHICLES 

Sec. 9-201. - [Sales of motor vehicles.] 
    It shall be illegal for any person to offer any motor vehicle for sale on any property (including private, public and on rights-of-way) except on property that is licensed and zoned for the sale of motor vehicles. Additionally, there shall be an exemption from this article for persons who may sell up to three motor vehicles that they own, per calendar year, on property on which they reside as the legal owner. 
(Ord. No. 2313, § 1, 11-23-09) 
Sec. 9-202. - Nuisance declared. 
    The violation of the above section shall be deemed to be a public nuisance and a menace to the health and safety of the citizens of the city. The police department of the city shall be authorized to abate the public nuisance by impounding and removing any motor vehicle offered for sale in violation of this article. The motor vehicle may be impounded, removed and stored at an authorized location and the costs of such removal and storage shall be at the expense of the owner of such motor vehicle. Such motor vehicles shall be removed within 48 hours of their being illegally offered for sale or when the property owner makes a request to the police department or engineering department that such motor vehicles be removed, whichever is sooner. Motor vehicles impounded pursuant to this section may be sold as abandoned property, if not redeemed by the owner of such motor vehicle within 60 days of the impoundment of such motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2313, § 2, 11-23-09) 
Sec. 9-203. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the said terms and provisions of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished in accordance with Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-9, for a misdemeanor violation for each such offense. Each day any violation of this article shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. This penalty shall be in addition to that abatement of public nuisance as provided in the above section. 
(Ord. No. 2313, § 3, 11-23-09) 
Chapter 10 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- General penalty, § 1-5; city attorney, § 2-81 et seq. 
State Law reference- Power of city to enforce ordinances, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-1; municipal courts, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-1 et seq.; bail, ARCrP Rule 7.2; magistrates, ARJA Rule 18; uniform traffic infractions, ARJA Rule 19. 
State Constitution reference- Municipal courts, Ala. Const., Amendment No. 328, § 6.065. 

Sec. 10-1. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a municipal court for the city (the "municipal court") pursuant to the provisions of Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 1, 11-21-77) 
Sec. 10-2. - Jurisdiction. 
    The municipal court shall have jurisdiction of all prosecutions for the breach of ordinances of the city within its corporate limits and police jurisdiction. This jurisdiction shall also extend to all prosecutions for violations of state misdemeanors committed within the corporate limits and the police jurisdiction of the city where such offenses have been made against the city. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 2, 11-21-77) 
Cross reference- State offenses adopted, § 1-26 et seq. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-1. 
Sec. 10-3. - Time and place of holding court. 
    The municipal court shall hold court at such time and place as the governing body may determine with the advice of the municipal judge. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 3, 11-21-77) 
Sec. 10-4. - Judge-Generally. 
(a)  The municipal court shall consist of one municipal judge to be appointed by a vote of a majority of the members elected or appointed to the city council. The judge shall be appointed for a term of two years and shall be eligible for reappointment upon the expiration of his term. He shall hold office until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(b)  The municipal judge must be licensed to practice law in the state and must be a qualified elector of the state. No judge shall be otherwise employed in any capacity by the city during his term of office. 
(c)  The office of municipal judge shall be vacant if he dies, resigns or is removed, and vacancies shall be filled by the city council in the same manner as original appointments are made. Any person so appointed shall be eligible to serve two years from the date of appointment. 
(d)  The municipal judge shall, before assuming office, take and sign the oath provided by the state constitution, and a copy thereof shall be filed in the office of the secretary of state of Alabama, the state administrative director of courts and the clerk of the city. 
(e)  The municipal judge shall be subject to all grounds of disqualification from hearing specific cases that are applicable to circuit court judges. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 4, 11-21-77) 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Constitution reference- Oath of office, Ala. Const., Art. XVI, § 279. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-30. 
Sec. 10-5. - Same-Compensation. 
    The annual salary of the municipal judge is hereby fixed at $2,400.00 and shall be payable in 12 equal monthly installments. This salary shall not be diminished during the judge's term of office. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 5, 11-21-77) 
Sec. 10-6. - Powers. 
(a)  Bond. The municipal judge shall have the power to admit to bail any person charged with the violation of any city ordinance by requiring an appearance bond, with good security, to be approved by the municipal judge or his designee in an amount not to exceed $500.00 and may, in his discretion, admit to bail such persons on a personal recognizance bond conditioned on the appearance of such persons before him on a day named therein to answer the charges preferred against them. 
(b)  Penalties. Except as otherwise provided in this Code or by applicable law, the municipal judge shall have the authority to punish any person convicted of violating any municipal ordinance with a fine of not more than $500.00 and/or a sentence of imprisonment or hard labor for a period not exceeding six months; provided, however, that no fine or sentence of imprisonment shall exceed the maximum fine or sentence provided by the city ordinance violated nor shall the fine or sentence exceed the maximum fine and sentence provided for violation of a substantially similar offense under state law. The penalty imposed on a corporation shall consist of the fine only, plus costs of court. 
(c)  Working out fines. The municipal judge in his judgment may provide that if a fine and costs are not paid within the time prescribed, the defendant, unless indigent, shall work out the amount of the judgment under the direction of the city authority, allowing not less than $10.00 for each day's service. 
(d)  Costs. 
(1)  An additional municipal court cost of $40.50 shall be added to each municipal court non-DUI traffic infraction case and each driver's license offense in Vestavia Hills Municipal Court; provided, however, the additional court cost to be added to each case of driving under the influence in violation of Code of Alabama 1975, title 32-5A-191, of Section 1-5, City of Vestavia Hills Code of Ordinances (Vestavia Hills Municipal Ordinance Number 1653) shall be a total of $40.50. 
(2)  An additional municipal court cost of $44.00 shall be added to each municipal court misdemeanor case other than those described in subsection (1). 
(3)  All proceeds from this court cost shall be deposited into the established account known as the City of Vestavia Hills Corrections Fund; and 
(4)  The funds contained in the corrections fund shall be expended as needed for the operation and maintenance of the municipal jail or jails, correctional facilities, juvenile detention center, or court complex, now existing or established after this date.

COURT APPEARANCE IS REQUIRED ON THE FOLLOWING CITATIONS 
1.  Reckless driving. 
2.  No driver's license. 
3.  Driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs. 
4.  Driving while license or privilege suspended. 
5.  Driving while license or privilege revoked. 
6.  Driving while license or privilege canceled. 
7.  Overweight truck. 
    Court appearance is also required on all other violations not listed above, and in cases where officer requires court appearance . 
(e)  Inability to pay. Upon conviction, the court may, upon a showing of inability to make immediate payment of fines and costs, accept defendant's bond with or without surety and with waiver of exemptions as to personally, such fines and costs to be payable within 90 days and, upon nonpayment of which execution may issue upon the bond as upon judgments in state courts. 
(f)  Discretion of judge. The municipal judge shall have the authority to continue a case from time to time to permit the fine and costs to be paid; remit fines, costs and fees; impose intermittent sentences; establish work release programs; require attendance of educational, corrective or rehabilitative programs; suspend driving privileges for such times and under such conditions as provided by law; and order hearings to determine the competency of the defendant to stand trial; provided further, that the judge may enter an order authorizing the defendant to drive under the conditions set forth in the order. 
(g)  Trial. All cases in the municipal court shall be tried by a municipal judge without a jury. 
(h)  Probation. The municipal judge may suspend execution of sentence and place a defendant on probation for varying periods of time, not to exceed two years, under the procedures and conditions set out in Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-13. 
(i)  Oaths; evidence; contempt; process; designees. The municipal judge may administer oaths, compel the attendance of witnesses and compel the production of books and papers, punish by fine not exceeding $50.00 and/or imprisonment not exceeding five days any person found and adjudged to be in contempt of court, and shall have power coextensive with the jurisdiction of the district court to issue writs and other process and to approve and declare bonds forfeited. The municipal judge shall designate any other municipal officers who shall be authorized to approve appearance and appeal bonds. 
(j)  Judicial notice. The municipal court shall take judicial notice of the ordinances of the city. 
(k)  Execution of warrants, etc. The sheriff of the county and all law enforcement officers of the city shall obey the municipal judge having legal authority in faithfully executing the warrants and processes committed to them for service according to their mandates. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 6, 11-21-77; Ord. No. 580, 7-20-81; Ord. No. 1652, §§ I-IV, 10-21-96; Ord. No. 2013, §§ I-IV, 9-3-03) 
State Law reference- Working out amount of judgment when not paid, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-12; costs in municipal court, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 12-14-14, 12-19-153; fair trial tax, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-19-250 et seq.; costs, etc., generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-19-150 et seq.; cancellation, suspension or revocation of driver's license, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-195. 
Sec. 10-7. - Warrants. 
    The municipal judge is authorized to issue arrest and search warrants, upon affidavit or deposition as required by law, for city ordinance violations returnable to the municipal court and for violations of state law returnable to any state court. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 9, 11-21-77) 
State Law reference- Search warrants, Code of Ala. 1975, § 15-5-1 et seq.; warrants of arrest, Code of Ala. 1975, § 15-7-3 et seq. 
Sec. 10-8. - Magistrates. 
    The municipal judge shall take steps to have a magistrate appointed for the city pursuant to Rule 18 of the Alabama Rules of Judicial Administration. The powers of the magistrate shall be limited to: 
(1)  Issuance of arrest warrants. 
(2)  Granting of bail under the direction of the court in minor misdemeanor prosecutions. 
(3)  Receiving of pleas of guilty in minor misdemeanors where a schedule of fines has been suggested by rule. 
(4)  Accountability to the municipal court for all uniform traffic tickets and complaints, moneys received and records of offenses. 
(5)  Such other authority as may be granted by law. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 10, 11-21-77) 
State Law reference- Powers of magistrates, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-51. 
Sec. 10-9. - Acting municipal judge. 
    In the event of the absence from the city, death, disability or disqualification of a municipal judge for any reason, the mayor shall have the authority to designate a person licensed to practice law in the state and a qualified elector of the state, not otherwise employed in any capacity by the city, to serve as acting municipal judge with all power and authority of a duly appointed municipal judge. No such acting judge may serve for more than 30 successive days or a total of 60 days in any calendar year; provided, that during the time that the duly appointed municipal judge is disqualified pursuant to the constitution, the time of service limitations for acting judges shall not apply. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 11, 11-21-77) 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 
Sec. 10-10. - Reports-Monthly. 
    The municipal judge shall be required to make a report to the council on the operation of the municipal court every month. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 13, 11-21-77) 
Sec. 10-11. - Same-Legal requirements. 
    The municipal judge shall report on the proceedings of the municipal court as required by law or rule. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 12, 11-21-77) 
State Law reference- Monthly reports of clerk of court as to fines, fees, etc., collected, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-1-19; report by city as to court proceedings, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-16. 
Sec. 10-12. - Powers of mayor. 
    The mayor may remit fines and such costs as are payable to the city and commute sentences imposed by municipal judges or the court to which an appeal was taken for violations of city ordinances, and may grant pardons, after conviction, for violation of such ordinances, and he shall report his action to the council at the first regular meeting thereof in the succeeding month with his reasons therefor in writing. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 7, 11-21-77) 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 
Sec. 10-13. - Appeals. 
(a)  Where taken. All appeals from judgments of the municipal court shall be to the circuit court of the circuit in which the violation occurred for trial de novo. 
(b)  By city. The city may appeal within 60 days, without bond, from a judgment of the municipal court holding a city ordinance invalid. 
(c)  By defendant. A defendant may appeal in any case within 14 days from the entry of judgment by filing notice of appeal and giving bond, with or without surety, approved by the court or the clerk in an amount of not more than $500.00 and costs, as fixed by the court, conditioned upon defendant's appearance before the circuit court. The municipal court may waive appearance bond upon a satisfactory showing that the defendant is indigent or otherwise unable to provide a surety bond. If an appeal bond is waived, a defendant sentenced to imprisonment shall not be released from custody, but may obtain release at any time by filing a bond approved by the municipal court. If the defendant is not released, the prosecutor shall notify the circuit clerk and the case shall be set for trial at the earliest practicable time. 
(d)  Record. When an appeal has been taken, the city shall file the notice and other documents in the court to which the appeal is taken within 15 days, failing which the city shall be deemed to have abandoned the prosecution, the defendant shall stand discharged and the bond shall be automatically terminated. 
(e)  Penalty. Upon a trial or plea of guilty in the circuit court on appeal, the court may impose any penalty or sentence which the municipal court could have imposed. 
(f)  Dismissal. Upon the failure of an appellant to appear in the circuit court when the case is called for trial, unless good cause for such default is shown, the court shall dismiss the appeal and enter judgment of default on the appeal bond, and may also issue a warrant for the arrest of the appellant. A copy of the order shall be delivered by the circuit clerk to the clerk of the municipal court. The circuit court may, on motion of the defendant made within 30 days of the order of dismissal, set aside the dismissal and other orders and reinstate the appeal on such terms as the court may prescribe for good cause shown by the defendant. 
(g)  Arrest. Upon the receipt of notice of dismissal of an appeal, the municipal court may issue a warrant for the arrest of the defendant, who may also be arrested without a warrant as an escapee. Upon arrest, the defendant shall be delivered to the city authorities and punished in accordance with the judgment of the municipal court. 
(h)  Judgment against defendant. If a judgment is entered against a defendant on appeal, the circuit court shall remand the defendant to the city authorities for punishment in accordance with the judgment of the circuit court, unless, when the judgment is for fine and costs only, the judgment is paid or a judgment is conferred therefor in favor of the city with sureties or as otherwise provided for convictions under state law. 
(i)  Disposition of fines, costs. Upon receipt of payment of fines, forfeitures and costs upon appeals, the clerk of the circuit court shall within 30 days pay 90 percent of such fines and forfeitures, and ten percent of the costs, to the treasurer of the city. The circuit clerk shall be liable on his bond for such fines and costs plus a penalty of five percent per month for default in such payments; 
(j)  Appeal to court of criminal appeals. From the judgment of the circuit court, the city, in a case holding invalid an ordinance, or the defendant in any case, may appeal to the court of criminal appeals in like manner as in cases of appeals for convictions of violation of the criminal laws of the state. If the appeal is taken by the city, it shall not be required to give surety for the cost of the appeal. When taken by the defendant, he may give bail with sufficient sureties, conditioned that he will appear and abide by the judgment of the appellate court, and failing to give bail he must be committed to the city jail; but he may give such bail at any time pending the appeal. When an appeal is taken by the defendant and bail is given pending the appeal, and the judgment of conviction is affirmed or the appeal is dismissed, the defendant is bound by the undertaking of bail to surrender himself to the city authorities within 15 days from the date of such affirmance or dismissal, and if he shall fail to do so, the clerk of the circuit court from which the appeal is taken, upon motion of the city, must endorse the bail bond forfeited, and a writ or writs of arrest must be issued by the clerk to the sheriff. Upon arrest the defendant shall be delivered to the city authorities and the sentence must without delay be carried out as if no appeal had been taken. If bail is forfeited as provided in this section, a conditional judgment must be entered by the court in favor of the city and the same proceedings had thereon for the city as is authorized by law to be had in the name of the state in state cases. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 8, 11-21-77) 
Sec. 10-14. - Educational programs. 
(a)  There is hereby established an alcohol abuse educational program to be known as the highway intoxication seminar, which shall be under the supervision of the clerk of the municipal court. Each person attending the seminar shall be charged no more than $300.00 for evaluation and/or registration. Such fees are to be assessed by the judge of the municipal court as appropriate, unless the same is waived by the municipal judge or by the clerk of municipal court in such cases where the individual is being referred by an outside agency. 
(b)  There is hereby established a traffic safety educational program, which shall be under the supervision of the clerk of the municipal court. Each person attending the seminar shall be charged not more than $150.00 for registration. Such fees are to be assessed by the judge of the municipal court as appropriate, unless the same is waived by the municipal judge or by the clerk of municipal court in such cases where the individual is being referred by an outside agency. 
(c)  There is hereby established an advisory committee consisting of the presiding municipal judge or his designee, the chief of police or his designee, and the city attorney or his designee. 
(d)  The clerk of the municipal court shall be responsible for scheduling of classes, instructors and facilitators and setting reasonable fees for the payment of the instructors and facilitators. The clerk of municipal court shall adopt rules and regulations for the operation of the established educational programs, criteria for acceptance and completion and established fees for the appropriate program. These rules and regulations, policy and procedures, and fee list shall be readily available for public inspection. If, for any reason, a class needs to be rescheduled or cancelled, a penalty of $25.00 shall be charged from fees already collected. 
(e)  All monies collected as a result of the operation of the alcohol abuse education program and the traffic safety education program in the form of registration fees, evaluation fees and/or tuition fees shall be maintained in a separate account with the city finance department to be distributed as follows: 
(1)  To fully cover the cost of services provided by the previously mentioned education programs; 
(2)  An amount equivalent to $40.50 per individual participant to the city's "Court and Correction Fund"; and 
(3)  An amount equivalent to $10.00 per applicant to the "Municipal Court Judicial Administrative Fund"; and 
(4)  An amount equivalent to $37.00 per applicant along with all rescheduling fees shall be applied to the city's "General Fund"; and 
(5)  All remaining monies to be used for the purpose of providing various other traffic safety education and awareness programs to the Vestavia Hills community through the traffic safety office of the Vestavia Hills Police Department or any other police activities including training of officers. The collection and use of these monies shall be under the supervision of the police chief and finance director. 
(Ord. No. 2427, §§ 1-5, 12-26-12; Ord. No. 2464 , §§ 4, 5, 9-23-13) 
Chapter 11 - OFFENSES-MISCELLANEOUS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Personal property taken up and stored by city, § 2-1. 
State Law reference- Alabama Criminal Code, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 11-1. - False report. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person maliciously or willfully to give, in writing, orally or by any means of communication, any false information or false report calculated to cause a law enforcement official or municipal agency to respond thereto or to do or perform some act or render some service. The term "municipal agency" as used in this section shall mean any agent, servant, officer or employee of Vestavia Hills, Alabama. 
(Ord. No. 375, § 1, 7-18-77) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 6. 
State Law reference- False reporting to law enforcement authorities, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-10-9; unsworn falsification to authorities, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-10-109; falsely reporting an incident, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-11-11. 
Sec. 11-2. - Impersonation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent himself to be or assume to be an officer or employee of the city or attempt, without the proper legal authority, to exercise the power and authority of an officer or employee of the city, or without authority from the city, to wear the uniform, cap, badge or insignia or carry the club of a policeman, or without authority from the city, to wear the uniform, cap, badge or insignia of a fireman of the city. 
(Ord. No. 303, § 1, 3-3-75) 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Criminal impersonation, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-9-18; impersonating public servant, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-10-10; impersonating peace officer, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-10-11. 
Sec. 11-3. - Indecent exposure, prostitution, etc.-Definitions. 
    For all purposes of section 11-4: 
    Act of prostitution shall mean and include, without limiting its definition otherwise, one engaging in sexual intercourse for hire, whether by the payment of money or other material consideration, with one other than the legal spouse of the person engaging in such activity. 
    Streaking shall mean and include appearing, exhibiting or presenting oneself in any public place or on the private property of another or running across or through any public place or the private property of another without clothing covering his or her private parts or sexual organs. 
(Ord. No. 296, § 2, 4-15-74) 
Sec. 11-4. - Same-Prohibited. 
    No person in the city shall: 
(1)  Engage in streaking in any public place or on the private property of another. 
(2)  Expose or exhibit his or her sexual organs or private parts in any public place or on the private premises of another, or so near thereto as to be seen from such private premises, in a vulgar or indecent manner. 
(3)  Commit or agree to commit a lewd act or an act of prostitution or moral perversion. 
(4)  Secure or offer another for the purpose of committing a lewd act or an act of prostitution or moral perversion. 
(5)  Be in any place frequented by the public, or any public place, for the purpose of inducing, enticing or procuring another to commit a lewd act or an act of prostitution or moral perversion. 
(6)  Make a meretricious display in or near any public place, or any place frequented by the public, or any place open to the public. 
(7)  Knowingly transport any person to any place for the purpose of committing a lewd act or an act of prostitution or moral perversion. 
(8)  Knowingly receive, or offer or agree to receive, any person into any place or building for the purpose of performing a lewd act, or any act of prostitution or moral perversion, or to knowingly permit any person to remain in any place or building for any such purpose. 
(9)  Direct or offer to direct any person to any place or building for the purpose of committing any lewd act or act of prostitution or moral perversion. 
(10)  Aid, abet, allow, permit or participate in the commission of any of the acts prohibited in this section. 
(Ord. No. 296, § 1, 4-15-74) 
State Law reference- Indecent exposure, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-6-68; prostitution offenses, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-12-110 et seq.; public lewdness, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-12-130. 
Sec. 11-5. - Throwing stones, etc.-Buildings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw any stone or missile at, into or against any dwelling, schoolhouse, public building or other building within the city. 
(Ord. No. 31, 10-20-54) 
Cross reference- School buildings, § 5-91 et seq. 
Sec. 11-6. - Same-Public gatherings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw any fireworks, bottles, magazine, rolled paper, cushion, rock, stocks, ice, paper cup or other object or substance of any type or kind into the crowd or otherwise at any athletic event or other public gathering of any type or kind held on public property within the city; except, however, that the throwing of objects by athletic team members while engaging in the aforementioned athletic events shall not be a violation hereof. 
(Ord. No. 289, § 1, 12-3-73) 
Secs. 11-7, 11-8. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2309, § 1, adopted Nov. 23, 2009, repealed §§ 11-7, 11-8 in their entirety, which pertained to carrying weapon-prohibited, same-mitigation, respectively, and derived from Ord. No. 88, §§ 1, 3, adopted Sept. 4, 1962. 
Sec. 11-9. - Discharging firearm or air rifle. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge within the city or the police jurisdiction thereof any firearm or air rifle, except in the reasonable defense of his person or property; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to peace officers or members of the armed forces of the state or the United States who discharge firearms in the performance of their duties as such officers. 
(Ord. No. 31, 10-20-54) 
Sec. 11-10. - Hazardous accumulations-Prohibited. 
(1)  Definitions. The following terms are defined for the purposes of this ordinance. 
    Junk vehicles, as used in this section, refers to vehicles left unused for a period exceeding 60 days, vehicles supported by any artificial means for a period exceeding 60 days and/or vehicles left on a premises in an inoperable condition for longer than 60 days; this definition is not intended to include vehicles of a recreational, antique or collectible nature that are in working condition and used by the person(s) owning or controlling the subject premises; this definition does not include abandoned vehicles as referenced in this section. 
    Person, as used in this section, shall include and be applicable to firms, corporations and associations, as well as to individuals. 
    Public nuisance, as used in this section, is defined as any situation that exists on the subject premises that creates a condition that endangers the public health, safety, morals, comfort or welfare of the community or any portion thereof, including buildings situated on the subject premises that present conditions that constitute a potential fire hazard or potential health hazard. 
    Pooled water, as used in this section, is defined as a small body of nonflowing standing water or standing water found in containers, tires or ornamental fixtures that is in a condition conducive to the harboring of mosquito larvae. 
    Rubbish, as used in this section, is defined as useless or rejected objects or junk. 
    Trash, as used in this section, shall mean improperly disposed of waste material or garbage. 
(2)  [Accumulations prohibited.] Every person owning any premises or property in the city or its police jurisdiction, shall keep the same free from overgrown vegetation, rubbish, trash, tires, junk vehicles, flammable or toxic materials, pooled water and other like public nuisances which create a hazardous condition or are favorable to the harboring of mosquitoes or other insects or vermin. Every such person who shall allow such accumulations on the premises that such person owns shall be punished as for a violation in this section. 
(3)  [Hazardous conditions.] Any growth of vegetation on an improved lot or unimproved lot that has been previously cleared of vegetation, if adjacent to another improved lot, beyond the height of 12 inches, or any substantive accumulation of rubbish, trash, tires, stored vehicles, flammable or toxic materials, pooled water and other like public nuisances shall be deemed favorable to the harboring of mosquitoes, insects or vermin and/or are deemed to create a hazardous condition, within the meaning of this section. 
(4)  [Height of vegetation.] It is not the intent of this section to enforce the maintenance of the height of vegetation in an area or on an unimproved lot that the public or any prudent person would consider a natural area, nature preserve or naturally occurring wooded lot; however, such areas are intended to be maintained free of all other public nuisances in subsection (3). 
(5)  [Written notice of violation required.] Whenever any police official, fire official or other duly appointed agent of the city shall discover any premises in the city in violation of subsection (2), the official or agent shall give written notice to the owner[s] of the premises or property to bring the condition[s] in compliance with this section. 
Said notice shall be in substantially the following form: 
NOTICE 
    To the owner or owners of [here describe the property] in the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama: 
    You are hereby notified that there exists on the above mentioned property (check all that apply): 
? a growth of vegetation above the height of 12 inches, ? an accumulation of trash or rubbish (describe) _____ , ? an accumulation of flammable or toxic material (describe) _____ , ? an accumulation of tires, ? junk vehicle[s], ? pooled water, ? another form of public nuisance (describe) _____  
in violation of Section 2 of Ordinance 1951 adopted by the City Council of the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama on November 4, 2002, and you are further notified that if said condition(s) are not abated within ten days of this notice you will be presented with an order to appear before the Municipal Court of the City of Vestavia Hills for a hearing on the matter. 
This the ____________ / ____________ / ____________ day of ____________ / ____________ / ____________ , 2 ____________ .

Said notice shall be in substantially the following form: 
NOTICE 
    To the owner or owners of [here describe the property] in the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama: 
    You are hereby notified that there continues to exist on the above mentioned property (check all that apply): 
? a growth of vegetation above the height of 12 inches, ? an accumulation of trash or rubbish (describe) _____ , ? an accumulation of flammable or toxic material (describe) _____ , ? an accumulation of tires, ? junk vehicle[s], ? pooled water, ? another form of public nuisance (describe) ____________  
in violation of Section 2 of Ordinance 1951 adopted by the City Council of the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama on November 4, 2002. Pursuant to this ordinance you were notified on [insert date of original notice] of this violation and given ten days to correct the condition[s] to bring the premises into compliance with Ordinance 1951. You are further notified that a hearing will be conducted by the Municipal Judge of the City of Vestavia Hills in the Municipal Complex located at 513 Montgomery Hwy. at ____________ / ____________ / ____________ p.m. on the ____________ / ____________ / ____________ day of ____________ , at which time and place you are directed to appear and show cause, if any you can, why the existence of said conditions should not be declared in violation of Ordinance 1951 and an order issued requiring the abatement of said conditions. 
You are hereby further notified that if said condition(s) are not abated within five days after same has been ordered, the Chief of Police, Fire Marshal or duly authorized agent of the City of Vestavia Hills will enter upon said premises and will have the condition(s) removed at your cost and expense pursuant to the schedule set forth in Section 10 of Ordinance 1951, and will assess the said cost against you and the above-described property, and that said expense will constitute a lien on said property.
