ARTICLE II. - PARKS AND RECREATION BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2258, §§ 1-7, adopted May 27, 2009, amended Art. II in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former Art. II, §§ 12-16-12-24, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 597, §§ 1-7, adopted Dec. 7, 1981. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 12-16. - Creation. 
    A Park and Recreation Board of the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama, a municipal corporation, (hereinafter referred to as "the board"), be and the same is hereby created and established as an agency or board of the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama, pursuant to the provisions of Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-86-1. Ordinance Number 319 previously enacted on October 20, 1975, and Ordinance Number 590, previously enacted on August 17, 1981, are hereby repealed so that the same shall be null and void. 
(Ord. No. 2258, § 1, 5-27-09) 
Sec. 12-17. - Composition and term of office. 
    The board shall consist of seven members, namely, the Mayor of the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama, as an ex officio member; one member of the city council appointed by the city council as an ex officio member; and five other residents of Vestavia Hills, who have recognized interest in recreational activities and who shall be selected and appointed by the city council. The mayor shall serve as an member of the board concurrently with the term of office of the Mayor of Vestavia Hills. The member of the city council shall serve as an member of the board at the pleasure of the city council. These seven members shall constitute the voting membership of the Park and Recreation Board of the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama. 
    The term of each appointed member shall be five years or until his or her successor takes office, except that the respective terms of the five members first appointed shall be one, two, three, four, and five years. 
(Ord. No. 2258, § 2, 5-27-09) 
Sec. 12-18. - Vacancies. 
    As the terms of voting members expire, their successors shall be selected for terms of five years each. Vacancies in unexpired terms shall be filled in the same manner as original appointments are made. 
    On or before the first regular December meeting of the city council in each calendar year, successors shall be elected as members of the board whose terms of office expire at the end of said year, such members to serve five years or until their successors are elected and qualified, and shall enter upon their duties at the first meeting of the board in the following month of January. In the event of death or resignation of any member of the board prior to the expiration of his or her term of appointment, the city council shall proceed forthwith to elect a successor who shall serve out the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 2258, § 3, 5-27-09) 
Sec. 12-19. - Compensation. 
    Members of the Vestavia Hills Park and Recreation Board shall serve without compensation. In the event it is necessary for a more efficient performance of their duties for any member or committee of members, to make trips in connection with board business, the board shall be authorized to reimburse said member or members for actual traveling and living expenses incurred. However, said member or members must give 14 days' advance written notice to the board prior to any trip stating the following: 
(1)  Date of trip; 
(2)  Length of trip; 
(3)  Purpose of trip; 
(4)  Anticipated cost of said trip; 
(5)  Itinerary of trip; and 
(6)  Destination. 
    Reimbursement of said actual living and travel expenses shall be made only after approval of said trip by the board after receipt of said written notice and prior to said trip and upon presentation of fully detailed and itemized vouchers and receipts. 
(Ord. No. 2258, § 4, 5-27-09) 
Sec. 12-20. - Operation. 
    The board shall elect from its membership, a president, vice-president and secretary and such other officers as it deems necessary to serve at its pleasure. The board shall adopt rules and regulations covering the procedures of the board and the use of lands, buildings, equipment and other facilities under its jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 2258, § 5, 5-27-09) 
Sec. 12-21. - Powers and duties. 
    The board shall be responsible for the direction, supervision and promotion of such recreational programs as will contribute to the general welfare of the residents of the county or municipality. The board shall have control over all lands, buildings, equipment and other facilities assigned for recreational purposes to the board by the municipal governing body or purchased or leased by it from funds provided by the municipal governing body; provided, however, that such control is subject to Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-47-19, 11-47-211, being the three statutes cited in the premises above. The board shall cooperate with other local agencies and state and federal agencies for the purpose of maintaining and improving recreational services and facilities for the municipality, including specifically, but not limited to, the city council of the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama. The board shall have power to accept financial and other aid and grants from any public and private agency. 
    Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the Board shall have power to manage all park and recreational property owned by or under the control of the city by purchase or gift, land, money, securities, building, books, sporting equipment or other property, real or personal, for park and recreational uses and purposes; to transfer in the name of the city, any equipment, books or other personal property, or any lease upon land for which it may have negotiated, to provide for the erection and rental of gymnasiums, swimming pools, community houses, playgrounds, rifle or pistol ranges, and other special types of recreational buildings and facilities, and to maintain the same; to provide its own by-laws, rules and regulations for its own governance of its officials and employees, and for the governance of the buildings and recreational facilities under its supervision and control. 
    Vacancies in the position of director of parks and recreation shall be filled in the following manner: 
(1)  Upon request of the mayor, the Jefferson County Personnel Board, pursuant to the laws of the State of Alabama shall submit a list of the most qualified candidates. 
(2)  The mayor shall assemble a search committee comprised of: the mayor, the president of the parks and recreation board or a member as appointed by the president of the parks and recreation board; and the current ex officio member of the city council. This committee shall individually interview the candidates for the position. 
(3)  The mayor, as appointing authority of the city, shall recommend a candidate to fill the position to the city council. 
(4)  The city council shall appoint a director. 
(Ord. No. 2258, § 6, 5-27-09) 
Sec. 12-22. - Budget and financial matters. 
    The board shall adopt, at its regular meeting in the month of June of each year, a detailed budget of estimated revenues and expenditures for the next following year, which shall be transmitted to the mayor to follow the current budgetary procedures. The mayor shall present the requests as he recommends to the city council. Upon receipt of such estimated budget, the city council shall appropriate and set aside, for the use of the board, for the maintenance of the park and recreation system of the city, funds in an amount equal to all or such part of said estimated budget as may be available or deemed proper by the city council. 
    Requisitions and vouchers for payment shall be directed to the city's financial office pursuant to the city's current standard operating procedures. 
(Ord. No. 2258, § 7, 5-27-09) 
Chapter 13 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 8; parks and recreation, Ch. 12; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 15; utilities, Ch. 17. 
State Law reference- Planning, zoning and subdivisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-1 et seq.; regional planning and development, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-85-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Municipal services to be provided to property within city limits; exceptions. 
(a)  Effective October 20, 1986, the city shall furnish municipal services only to those persons, firms, corporations, partnerships and other owners of real property, which said real property is situated in the corporate city limits of the city, except for those certain exceptions set forth in subsection (c) hereof. 
(b)  Effective October 20, 1986, the city shall not furnish any municipal services to any owner of real estate which said real estate is located outside the corporate boundaries of the city, except for those certain exceptions set forth in paragraph (c) hereof. 
(c)  Exceptions. 
(1)  Pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-141 et seq., whenever the necessity arises during any emergency resulting from fire or other public disaster, the firemen of the city may, together with all necessary equipment, lawfully go or be sent beyond the corporate limits and police jurisdiction of said city to any point within the State of Alabama to assist in meeting such emergency. 
(2)  Pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-142, the governing body of the city may, in its discretion, authorize or require the fire department thereof to render aid in cases of fire occurring beyond the corporate limits and/or police jurisdiction. 
(3)  Pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-40-10, the ordinances of the city enforcing police regulations and prescribing fines and penalties for violations thereof shall have force and effect in the police jurisdiction, as well as the corporate city limits. 
(4)  The governing body of the city may, in its discretion, authorize or require the police department thereof to patrol certain areas in the city's police jurisdiction and/or to render aid in cases of extreme emergency or public disaster. 
(5)  Pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-51-206, the city has the authority to levy and assess municipal sales taxes by ordinance within the police jurisdiction; provided that said levy and assessment shall not exceed one-half of the amount levied and assessed for like businesses, sales or uses conducted within the corporate limits. The city shall furnish police and fire services to all such entities located outside the corporate city limits, but within the police jurisdiction that collect and pay said sales taxes to the city on the basis described above and/or pay fees for said police and fire services. 
(6)  The city may furnish police and fire services to not-for-profit churches and schools located within the police jurisdiction of the city and not within the corporate city limits of another municipality. 
(7)  The city may furnish emergency medical services by and through its paramedics and/or firemen to citizens residing within the police jurisdiction of the city; provided said residents do not live within the corporate city limits of another municipality. 
(8)  The city may, pursuant to the authority of Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-142, enter into written contracts with the owners of property located beyond the corporate limits, but in the police jurisdiction, whereby the city agrees to furnish fire protection services in return for a valuable consideration. The city shall comply with the terms and provisions of said contracts provided the property owner does not become delinquent in the payments or default on the contract. 
(Ord. No. 664, §§ 1-3, 11-5-84; Ord. No. 870, §§ 1-3, 10-20-86) 
Sec. 13-2. - Annexed territory subject to laws, rules, etc., of city. 
(a)  Jurisdiction over annexed property. All territory brought within the corporate limits of the city by annexation shall be subject to the laws, rules, regulations and ordinances of the city, including specifically, but not limited to, the zoning ordinances, subdivision regulations and the Southern Building Code. The city council of the city shall have and exercise the same jurisdiction over such annexed territory as is exercised over the territory within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  Annexed property to be zoned. 
(1)  Authority. Pursuant to the authority vested in the city by virtue of the provisions of Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-70 et seq., the city council shall zone all property annexed to the corporate limits of the city. 
(2)  Intents and purpose. 
a.  In accordance with the provisions of Act Number 300 of the 1955 session of the Alabama Legislature, (Code of Alabama Recompiled, 1958, Appendix Section 985, Volume 14 at Page 397), the city council of the city intends to zone and regulate annexed territory as to the kind, character and use and structures and improvements. It is the intent of the city council that all real property located within the municipal corporate boundaries shall be governed by the laws, rules, regulations and ordinances of the city, rather than by those of Jefferson County. 
b.  At the present time, the city follows the annexation procedure outlined in Act Number 32 of the 1964 session of the Alabama Legislature to extend the corporate limits. Said act requires that the municipality shall hold a public hearing to determine the truth of the matters set forth in the petition for annexation and consider any written protests or objections regarding the proposed annexation. The public hearing on the annexation petition must be held not less than 90 days from the date of publication. It is the intent of the city council to conduct a public hearing on the zoning of the annexed territory immediately following the public hearing on the annexation petition. An ordinance zoning the annexed territory shall be adopted immediately after enactment of the ordinance annexing said property. 
(c)  Zoning classification. The application to zone or rezone the property sought to be annexed shall be initiated by the property owner or the owner's authorized agent by filing a petition concurrently with the petition for annexation. Any member of the city council may also initiate the rezoning of said territory by introduction of a resolution for such purpose. The zoning classification to be applied for shall be that Vestavia Hills classification closest to and most compatible with the Jefferson County classification applicable to the property at the time of filing the petition for annexation. Should two different Vestavia Hills zoning classifications be close to and compatible with the Jefferson County classification, then in such event the Vestavia Hills classification imposing greater restrictions shall be applied for. 
(d)  Procedures. 
(1)  Application. The zoning procedure shall be initiated by the filing of a petition by the owner of the land or upon the introduction of a resolution by any member of the city council. The correct names and addresses of all owners of property located in whole or in part within 500 feet from the boundaries of the property sought to be annexed and which is the subject of the proposed change in zoning classification as shown by the records of the office of the tax assessor of Jefferson County, Alabama, shall be furnished by the owner at said time. 
(2)  Schedule first hearing before planning and zoning board. The rezoning request shall be scheduled for hearing before the Vestavia Hills planning and zoning board. 
(3)  First notice to adjoining property owners. Pursuant to the requirements of Act Number 1123 of the Regular Session of the 1973 Alabama Legislature, the city shall give written notice a minimum of 15 days prior to the proposed date of the rezoning hearing before the planning and zoning board, to all owners of property located in whole or in part within 500 feet from the boundaries of the property, which is the subject of the proposed change in zoning classification as shown by the records of the office of the tax assessor of Jefferson County, Alabama. Such notice shall be deemed given when deposited in the United States mail, first-class postage prepaid, addressed to such property at their addresses as shown on the records of the office of the tax assessor of Jefferson County on the date such owners are determined. The cost of said mailing shall be paid by the owner of the property sought to be annexed. 
(4)  Public hearing by planning and zoning board. The Vestavia Hills planning and zoning board shall conduct a public hearing regarding the application for zoning change. At the conclusion of the public hearing, the Vestavia Hills planning and zoning board shall issue a report to the city council recommending that the application for zoning be either approved or denied. 
(5)  Schedule second hearing before city council. A public hearing on the matter of the application for rezoning shall be scheduled before the city council of the city. The date of said public hearing shall be the same date as the public hearing for the annexation petition itself. 
(6)  Second notice to adjoining property owners. Pursuant to the requirements of Act Number 1123 of the Regular Session of the 1973 Alabama Legislature, the city shall again give written notice a minimum of 15 days prior to the proposed date of the rezoning public hearing before the city council, to all owners of property located in whole or in part within 500 feet from the boundaries of the property, which is the subject of the proposed change in zoning classification, as shown by the records of the office of the tax assessor of Jefferson County, Alabama. 
(7)  Preparation of ordinance. An ordinance shall be prepared proposing to change the Jefferson County zoning classification on the territory sought to be annexed to the municipality to the closest and most compatible Vestavia Hills classification. 
(8)  First publication in newspaper. Pursuant to the requirements of Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-77, the proposed ordinance shall be published in full for one insertion and an additional insertion of a synopsis of the proposed ordinance, one week after the first insertion, which synopsis shall refer to the date and name of the newspaper in which the proposed ordinance was first published; both such insertions shall be at least 15 days in advance of its passage and in a newspaper of general circulation published within the municipality. 
(9)  First posting of proposed ordinance. The proposed ordinance shall be posted in four conspicuous places within the city, together with a notice stating the time and place that the ordinance is to be considered by the municipal legislative authorities and stating further that at such time and place all persons who desire shall have an opportunity of being heard in opposition to or in favor of such ordinance. The four places for posting shall be the United States post office, the mayor's office at Vestavia Hills city hall, the Sear's Mall and the Alabama ABC store. 
(10)  Public hearing by city council. The city council shall conduct public hearings on the petition for annexation and the petition for rezoning at the same meeting. The annexation ordinance shall be adopted first and the rezoning ordinance shall be adopted immediately thereafter. Rezoning is not completed without adoption and approval of said ordinance. 
(11)  Second publication of ordinance. After adoption, the ordinance shall be again published in some newspaper of general circulation in Jefferson County in accordance with Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-8. 
(12)  Second posting. After adoption, the ordinance shall again be posted at the United States post office, the mayor's office at Vestavia Hills City Hall, the Sear's mall and the Alabama ABC store. 
(13)  Publication expenses. All expenses incurred for the publication of said ordinances for annexation and rezoning shall be paid by the owner of the property. 
(Ord. No. 695, §§ I-IV, 3-5-84) 
Sec. 13-3. - All plot plans, building plans, specifications, surveys and resurveys to comply with legal requirements prior to submission. 
(a)  All plot plans, building plans and specifications, surveys and resurveys shall comply with all legal requirements of ordinances of the city prior to the time the same are submitted to the city council and/or planning and zoning board of the city. 
(b)  The following city employees and other officials shall examine the said plot plans, building plans and specifications, surveys and resurveys within seven days after the same are delivered to the city to determine whether or not said documents meet the legal requirements of the respective ordinances: 
Position Ordinance (1) Building inspector Zoning ordinance Building code Subdivision regulations Electrical code Plumbing code (2) City engineer Zoning ordinance Subdivision regulations (3) Fire inspector Fire code Building code (4) City attorney Zoning ordinance Subdivision regulations (5) City clerk Zoning ordinance Subdivision regulations (6) Council ex officio member on the planning and zoning board Zoning ordinance Subdivision regulations (7) Police chief Traffic recommendations (8) Fire chief Fire hydrant recommendations  
(c)  The above individuals shall certify in writing to the city council and the planning and zoning board that they have examined the documents and that they meet the requirements of the above ordinances. Should the documents fail to meet the said legal requirements, then in such event, they shall furnish written notice to the applicant setting forth the basis of non-compliance. 
(Ord. No. 704, §§ 1-3, 5-21-84) 
Sec. 13-4. - Comprehensive plan 2004-2025 adopted. 
(1)  The planning document entitled "City of Vestavia Hills Comprehensive Plan 2004-2025" and all official maps pertaining thereto, as amended, are hereby adopted the 21st day of June, 2004. 
(2)  The city clerk be and is hereby directed to publish Ordinance No. 2051, [from which this section derives] in accordance with the requirements of the law and to file a copy hereof, together with a duly certified copy of the "City of Vestavia Hills Comprehensive Plan 2004-2025", with the Probate Judge of Jefferson County, Alabama. 
(Ord. No. 2051, §§ 1, 2, 6-21-04) 
Secs. 13-5-13-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION 

Sec. 13-16. - Created. 
    Pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-1 et seq., there is hereby created a city planning commission for the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama, to consist of nine members, to be appointed for the term and in the manner set forth in said sections of the Code of Alabama 1975. 
(Ord. No. 7, § 1, 4-18-51) 
Sec. 13-17. - Master plan. 
    The city planning commission shall make and adopt a master plan for the physical development of the city, including any areas outside its boundaries which, in the commission's judgment, bear relation to the planning of the city. Such plan, with the accompanying maps, plats, charts and descriptive matter, shall show the commission's recommendations for the development of said territory, including, among other things, the general location, character and extent of streets, viaducts, subways, bridges, waterways, waterfronts, boulevards, parkways, playgrounds, squares, parks, aviation fields and other public ways, grounds and open spaces, the general location of public buildings and other public property, and the general location and extent of public utilities and terminals, whether publicly or privately owned or operated, for water, light, sanitation, transportation, communication, power and other purposes; also the removal, relocation, widening, narrowing, vacating, abandonment, change of use or extension of any of the foregoing ways, grounds, open spaces, buildings, property, utilities or terminals; as well as a zoning plan for the control of the height, area, bulk, location and use of buildings and premises. As the work of making the whole master plan progresses, said commission may from time to time adopt and publish a part or parts thereof, any such part to cover one or more major sections or divisions of the city, or one or more of the aforesaid or other functional matters to be included in the said plan. Said commission is hereby authorized and empowered to exercise all powers and do all things authorized to such commission by Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-1 et seq., as it may deem necessary for its work. Said commission is also authorized and empowered to exercise all powers and to do all things authorized to such commission by said sections of the Code of Alabama 1975 with reference to division of unimproved property within said city and to exercise all of the powers granted by law to a zoning commission of the city, and to act as such zoning commission. 
(Ord. No. 7, § 2, 4-18-51) 
State Law reference- Master plan, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-8 et seq.; control of subdivisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-30 et seq.; zoning commission, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-79. 
Sec. 13-18. - Powers of mayor and council. 
    The mayor and city council are hereby authorized to make all appointments and to exercise all authority as authorized by Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 7, § 3, 4-18-51) 
Cross reference- Mayor and council, § 2-16 et seq. 
Sec. 13-19. - Applications; fee; postponement. 
(a)  Any person applying for zoning or rezoning may postpone the zoning or rezoning only one time in a calendar year. 
(b)  Any application presented to the planning and zoning commission must be accompanied by a $25.00 fee. 
(Ord. No. 404, §§ 1, 2, 11-21-77)

ARTICLE III. - TREE COMMISSION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 13-31. - Established; membership. 
    There is hereby established a tree commission and that the mayor with the concurrence of the council, shall appoint to the tree commission one member of the city council, the mayor, the beautification board chairman, and the landscape committee chairman shall serve as ex-officio members. The council member term shall expire on the date that a newly elected council shall take office. In addition, the mayor shall appoint, with the concurrence of the council, nine additional persons in the city, three of which shall be appointed for one year, three of which shall be appointed for two years and three of which shall be appointed for three years, and following the initial appointment, two members shall be appointed annually to serve for a period of three years, and thereafter until their successors are appointed and qualified. Persons with special expertise may be added as needed who shall serve at the pleasure of the appointing authority. 
(Ord. No. 1224, § 1, 7-1-91; Ord. No. 1451, 6-20-94) 
Sec. 13-32. - Meetings. 
    The commission shall provide in its minutes for regular periodic meetings. Meetings may also be called by the mayor, by the council member, or by any two of the commission members, after giving not less than three days' notice of the date, time and place of the special meeting. 
(Ord. No. 1224, § 2, 7-1-91) 
Sec. 13-33. - Duties. 
    The tree commission shall make recommendations to the mayor and council on the needs of the municipality in connection with its tree planting program; shall recommend the type and kind of trees to be planted upon municipal streets, parks and other public places within the municipality; shall assist the mayor and council in providing information regarding the protection, maintenance, removal, and planting of trees on public property and, where requested by the owner, on private property; shall assist in making a master street plan by recommending the use and species of trees; shall recommend to the mayor and council which trees are considered unwanted weed trees, and identify and recommend removal of dead, dying, diseased or insect-infected trees; and shall make studies and report back to the mayor and council with recommendations on matters concerning trees in the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 1224, § 3, 7-1-91) 
Secs. 13-33-13-49. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IV. - DESIGN REVIEW BOARD 

Sec. 13-71. - Establishment. 
    A design review board for the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama, is hereby established and shall hereinafter be referred to as the DRB. 
(1)  Purpose. The purpose of design review is to assure compatibility and quality in the design of certain development types in order to protect the health, safety and general welfare of the city. Further, it is the intent of the DRB to: 
a.  Promote the general welfare of the citizens of Vestavia Hills by ensuring that proposed sites, buildings and landscaping enhance the environment and design of the city. 
b.  Assure pleasing, environmentally-friendly development that supports the economic viability of the community. 
c.  Protect and enhance the value of properties in Vestavia Hills. 
d.  Ensure that new development is in accordance with the City of Vestavia Hills Comprehensive Plan. 
(2)  Membership. The DRB shall consist of seven regular members, all of whom shall be residents of the City of Vestavia Hills. Members shall be nominated by the mayor and appointed by the city council for a term of three years. The members of the board should consist of at least one registered architect and one registered landscape architect. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term of any member. Members may be removed for cause by the city council, upon a recommendation by the mayor, and upon written charges and after a public hearing by the council. Members shall serve without compensation. The board shall have the power to seek technical advice from outside its own membership on any matter related to its powers and duties. 
(3)  Meetings, procedures, and records. Meetings of the DRB shall be held monthly or at the call of the chair. All meetings shall be open to the public, and the agenda shall be posted at the municipal center. The DRB shall elect a chair and vice-chair, and such other officers as the members may deem necessary. The board shall adopt and publish its own rules of procedure and keep minutes of its proceedings. 
(4)  Records. The DRB shall maintain a record of its meetings, actions, determinations and findings, according to Alabama law. 
(5)  Design review guidelines. The DRB shall consider, adopt, publish, and maintain design review guidelines, which it shall apply during consideration of the compatibility of proposed development with the planned image and character of the city. 
(6)  Duties. The duties of the DRB shall be: 
a.  To review, in a timely manner, in a public forum, proposed development within the city for compatibility with the letter and spirit of the design review guidelines. 
b.  To comment upon and make recommendations to applicants, in regard to compatibility of proposed development with the letter and spirit of the design review guidelines. 
c.  To certify completion of design review for all applications heard by the DRB. 
(7)  Conflicts of interest. At any time the DRB schedules review of a proposed development in which a member has ownership or any other vested interest, that member will so identify such interests, following which disclosure the member shall be excused by the chair. The excused member shall be forbidden from presenting, voting upon, or discussing the matter at hand, other than answering a direct question. 
(Ord. No. 2332, § 1, 12-13-10) 
Sec. 13-72. - Applicability. 
(a)  Until completion of design review has been certified by the DRB, no applicable permit shall be issued for: 
(1)  Any nonresidential and mixed-use developments involving exterior construction, alteration, renovation, relocation, demolition, addition, or landscaping; 
(2)  Any landscaping and architectural elements within entry common areas of residential subdivisions; 
(3)  Townhouse and multi-family developments (design review will address only frontage design, landscaping, and design of common open spaces). 
(b)  Any request for a special exception use, conditional use, master plan approval, or rezoning may be referred by the reviewing authority to the DRB for its recommendation prior to the reviewing authority's decision regarding the request. 
(c)  Any variance request submitted to the board of zoning adjustment involving the reduction of normally required setbacks, buffers, or landscaping shall be reviewed by the DRB and its recommendation submitted to the board prior to its decision on such request. 
(Ord. No. 2332, § 2, 12-13-10) 
Sec. 13-73. - Application requirements. 
    A detailed application package shall be made available by the zoning official, which shall include a list of plans and materials required for review by the DRB. 
(1)  Applications shall be submitted at least 15 working days prior to the next regularly scheduled meeting of the DRB. 
(2)  No application will be accepted unless all fees have been paid and a complete application has been submitted. Design review fees shall be as set from time to time by the council. 
(Ord. No. 2332, § 3, 12-13-10) 
Sec. 13-74. - Procedure. 
(a)  The department of building safety shall not issue a building permit until completion of design review has been certified by the DRB, if applicable. All actions, as may be required for a development application, by the planning and zoning commission, board of zoning adjustment, and the city council shall be completed prior to completion of design review; however, said bodies may refer any application of a type listed in section 13-72, applicability, to the DRB prior to that body's decision regarding the application. 
(b)  Nonresidential and mixed-use developments. Applicants are encouraged to meet with the DRB early in the design process to receive a preliminary indication of the suitability of site plan and other general design considerations. 
(Ord. No. 2332, § 4, 12-13-10) 
Chapter 14 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; animals and fowl, Ch. 4; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 6; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 8; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 9; parks and recreation, Ch. 12; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 15; utilities, Ch. 17; abandoned vehicles, § 9-136 et seq.; litter, § 11-12. 
State Law reference- Solid waste, Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-27-1 et seq.; municipal solid waste collection and disposal, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-47-135, 22-27-3, 22-27-5; hazardous wastes management, Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-30-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms, when used in this chapter, shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    City shall mean the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama. 
    Contractor shall mean the person, firm, corporation, partnership or other legal entity with whom the city contracts with for garbage, trash, leaves and other putrescible collection and disposal services. 
    Garbage shall mean and include all waste and discarded food, animal and vegetable matter (but not including liquid waste), all other putrescible materials, and all other waste substances when placed in garbage containers as herein described. 
    Garbage container shall mean and include a watertight receptacle or can having a capacity of not less than 15 gallons or more than 32 gallons, of substantial metal or weather resistant plastic construction, with a tight-fitting lid or cover, with not less than one handle on the lid or cover and two handles on the side of the receptacle which can be conveniently lifted or moved. 
    Nonresidential establishment shall mean all users of garbage service except churches and residential users. 
    Person shall mean and include a natural person, firm, association, partnership, corporation, trustee, executor, administrator or other legal entity, whether singular or plural, masculine or feminine, as the context may require. 
    Sanitary department shall mean the sanitary department of the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama. 
    Trash shall mean and include all nonputrescible rubbish, tree limbs, leaves, grass cuttings, debris and other nonputrescible solid waste substances not included in the definition of "garbage" as it appears in this section. 
(Ord. No. 229, § 2, 1-17 -72; Ord. No. 259, § 1, 12-18-72; Ord. No. 276, § 1, 6-4-73; Ord. No. 1341, § 1, 3-15-93) 
State Law reference- Definitions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-27-2. 
Sec. 14-2. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  No person shall throw, place or dispose of any trash, litter, garbage, refuse or like matter upon the property or premises of another person, or upon any property which is in the possession of another person. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sweep or throw trash, garbage or any other waste material into the streets, alleys or on the sidewalks of the city or upon the property within the limits under his control. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to hold for collection on his or any other property garbage which is exposed to the open air. 
(Ord. No. 259, § 3, 12-18-72; Ord. No. 276, § 4, 6-4-73; Ord. No. 1341, § 4, 3-15-93) 
Sec. 14-3. - Dumping regulations. 
(a)  Dumping earth material on public and private property. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or other entity to cause or permit the dumping or depositing of soil, rocks, dirt, gravel, mud or other earth material on any public or private property within the city except for the following purposes: 
(1)  Construction during the normal construction period; 
(2)  Grading during the normal grading period; 
(3)  Filling during the normal filling period; 
(4)  For growing grass and/or shrubs or trees; 
(5)  Cultivation. 
Any dumping or depositing of earth material as aforesaid shall be done under the supervision of the city engineer or the building inspector of the city. 
(b)  Dumping in public ways. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or other entity to dump or otherwise place any trash, garbage, leaves, dirt, construction materials, rubbish, tree limbs, grass cuttings, metal waste, concrete waste, scrap wood, debris and other nonputrescible solid waste substances in, over, along, upon or through any gutter, creek, drainage way or ditch in any street or public way or easement in the city. 
(c)  Garbage and trash ordinance. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained herein, the owners of property, both public and private shall have the right to place garbage, trash and other litter in authorized litter receptacles in order that the garbage and trash collector may remove the same from the property all in accordance with the terms and provisions of Ordinance Number 374, adopted on June 6, 1977. 
(d)  Penalty. Any person, firm, corporation or other entity violating any provision of this section shall be fined not less than $25.00 nor more than $500.00 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 1044, §§ 1-4, 5-1-89) 
Secs. 14-4-14-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION; DISPOSAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-16. - Penalties. 
    If any person violates the provisions of this article, in addition to other penalties the sanitary department shall have the discretion to discontinue service to such person. 
(Ord. No. 259, § 7, 12-18-72; Ord. No. 276, § 7, 6-4-73) 
Sec. 14-17. - Billing. 
(a)  All bills for service under this article shall be due and payable in advance either quarterly, semi-annually or annually, at the option of the applicant for service; provided, however, that at the beginning of the service, the person desiring service shall pay a pro rata charge for the quarter when such service is begun. The quarter shall begin on the first day of October, January, April and July of each year. 
(b)  The sanitary department will discontinue service when notified by the city clerk's office that payment has not been made as due. The service of any person so discontinued for nonpayment will be resumed at the time of the next scheduled delivery after payment is received. 
(Ord. No. 259, § 3, 12-18-72; Ord. No. 276, § 3, 6-4-73) 
Sec. 14-18. - Persons not using city services-Duty. 
    All persons in the city who do not use the services of the city for collection, hauling and disposing of refuse must store and dispose of their refuse in a manner approved by the county department of health and at the same frequency as the collection services of the city. 
(Ord. No. 229, § 1, 1-17:72) 
Sec. 14-19. - Same-Violations. 
    All violations of section 14-18 shall be reported to the county department of health. 
(Ord. No. 229, § 3, 1-17-72) 
Secs. 14-20-14-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RESIDENCES, ETC. 

Sec. 14-31. - Service; service requirements. 
    The sanitary department shall operate and maintain a garbage and trash collection, hauling and disposal service for single-family residences within the city and, in the discretion of the city, for single-family residences within its police jurisdiction. (Separate provisions will apply to apartments, offices and commercial establishments, but not churches.) In connection therewith the following services shall be rendered and the following requirements shall apply: 
(1)  The collection of garbage shall be made from single-family and multifamily residences twice weekly. In addition, there shall be a collection of trash once weekly. 
(2)  Garbage must be stored in a garbage container as herein defined. Use of plastic liners and bags is recommended. Garbage will not be collected from containers which do not meet city standards. 
(3)  The following items will not be collected: 
a.  Fireplace ashes. 
b.  Rocks and dirt. 
c.  Rubbish, limbs, brush or other debris resulting from the cleaning of lots or work preliminary or subsequent to collection. 
(4)  The following items will be collected by the contractor as trash under the outlined conditions in reasonable amounts. Excessive amounts of the items listed below will be subject to the fee prescribed in subsection 14-32(c). 
a.  Scrap lumber, plaster, roofing, bricks, sanding dust and other building debris resulting from building, construction repair or remodeling must be containerized and each container must not exceed 50 pounds in weight. 
b.  Tree limbs not exceeding four feet in length nor 50 pounds in weight. 
c.  Tree stumps not exceeding 50 pounds in weight. 
d.  Limbs must be separated from vines and both limbs and vines must be separated from other trash (example-leaves and grass clippings). 
(5)  Trash, leaves, limbs, bushes, etc., should be placed within five feet of the curbline. They should not be placed on the street or gutters. 
(6)  Trash should be set out the night before or prior to 7:00 a.m. on the morning of scheduled trash service. 
(7)  Dog and cat litter must be in a sealed plastic bag or container. 
(8)  Any dog which harasses city employees in any way must be leashed, chained, fenced or restrained on the scheduled days of service. 
(9)  Recyclables. The contractor, at no additional cost to the city shall collect recyclables once per week, from each residential unit within the city limits of the city. The contractor shall provide the containers for said recyclables. The recyclables to be collected are newspaper, aluminum cans, glass, plastic containers and tin cans. The contractor shall recycle said items or cause said items to be recycled. 
(10)  Curbside containers. At the present time approximately 2,250 residential units utilize plastic and/or rubber mobile carts (containers) at the curbside on collection days and also for removing said mobile carts (containers) after garbage and trash pick-up by the contractor. The contractor shall have no obligation to furnish the city or owners with any mobile cart or container. 
(11)  Renewal. The city and the contractor shall, in accordance with Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-16-51(a)(10), and by mutual agreement, have the right to renew this contract from time to time; provided, however: 
a.  No renewal term shall be for a period greater than three years; and 
b.  The terms and provisions of the contract shall remain substantially the same; and 
c.  The price to be paid by the city to the contractor shall remain the same except for increases in charges for landfill services as provided for in paragraph 11 of the contract and cost of living price increases as set forth in paragraph 19 of the contract, using as the basis of such computation the Revised Consumer's Price Index-Cities, published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor. 
(12)  Leaves. 
a.  The leaf machine will begin operation on October 1, and will discontinue operation on December 31. The leaf machine cannot operate during extremely wet or freezing weather. 
b.  Prior to and after the termination of the operation of the leaf machine, leaves and grass cuttings must be placed in covered containers or plastic bags in order to be picked up on the scheduled trash route. 
(Ord. No. 259, § 2, 12-18-72; Ord. No. 1341, § 2, 3-15-93) 
Sec. 14-32. - Fees in police jurisdiction. 
(a)  The fee or charge for regular service for single-family residences outside the city limits but within the city's police jurisdiction is $200.00 per year, payable in advance, or $60.00 per quarter, payable in advance. 
(b)  For the fees now or hereafter prescribed by the council, there will be a limit for garbage of an amount equal to four authorized containers per scheduled pickup. Any amount of garbage in excess of such maximum amount will result in an additional fee of $1.00 per additional container for each collection made. 
(c)  Extra trips of the trash truck shall be made by the contractor for a fee of $50.00, payable in advance. 
(Ord. No. 259, § 3, 12-18-72; Ord. No. 1341, § 3, 3-15-93) 
Secs. 14-33-14-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - NONRESIDENCES 

Sec. 14-41. - Service; service requirements. 
    The sanitary department shall operate and maintain a garbage and trash collection, hauling and disposal service for nonresidential establishments within the city and, in the discretion of the city, within its police jurisdiction. In connection therewith the following services shall be rendered and the following requirements shall apply: 
(1)  The collection of garbage shall be made from nonresidential establishments five times per week (on a daily basis Monday through Friday). In addition, wet garbage will be collected at the discretion of the city on Saturday. 
(2)  Garbage must be stored in a garbage container as defined in this article. 
(3)  Trash will be collected at least once per week or more often at the discretion of the sanitary department up to a maximum of five days per week (Monday through Friday). 
(Ord. No. 276, § 2, 6-4-73) 
Secs. 14-42-14-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LITTER 

Sec. 14-51. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following terms, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein: 
    Authorized litter receptacle shall mean a container of watertight construction with a tight-fitting lid or cover capable of preventing the escape of contents within. Such receptacles shall have handles or other means for safe and convenient handling and be of such size or sufficient capacity to hold all litter generated between collection periods and shall be in compliance with the regulations promulgated in Ordinance Number 374 adopted by the city council on June 6, 1977, and regulating the collection and pick up of garbage and trash. 
    Construction sites means any private or public property upon which repairs to existing buildings, construction of new buildings or demolition of existing structures is taking place. 
    Litter shall mean rubbish, refuse, waste material, garbage, dead animals or fowl, offal, paper, glass, cans, bottles, trash, scrap metal, debris or any foreign substance of whatever kind and description whether or not it is of value. Litter is also garbage, refuse, rubbish and all other waste material which, if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited, tends to create a danger to the public health, safety and general welfare of the city. 
    Private premises means all property including, but not limited to, vacant land or any land, building or other structure designed or used for residential, commercial, business, industrial, institutional or religious purposes, together with any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, fence, porch, steps, vestibule, mailbox and other structure appurtenant thereto. 
    Public place means any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways, lakes, rivers, watercourses or fountains and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds and buildings. 
(Ord. No. 747, § 1, 3-18-85) 
Sec. 14-52. - Public places. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, cause or allow to be thrown or dispose of in any manner any litter, garbage, waste or peelings of vegetables or fruits, rubbish, ashes, cans, bottles, wire, paper, cartons, boxes, parts of automobiles, wagons, debris, furniture, glass, oil, filthy or odoriferous objects or anything else of an unsightly or unsanitary nature along or near or on any public road, street, alley, parkway, park drive, highway, ditch or any land adjoining any public road or highway or ditch in the city, except in a proper authorized litter receptacle maintained on public property for that specific purpose. It shall also be unlawful to place, throw or dispose of any hazardous obstruction or material tending to injure any person, animal, vehicle or tire using any sidewalk, street, alley, driveway or property, except that such may be placed in a proper authorized litter receptacle or near such a receptacle for immediate pick up. 
(Ord. No. 747, § 2, 3-18-85) 
Sec. 14-53. - Private property. 
    The owner or person in control of any private premises shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter. The owner or person in control of private premises shall maintain authorized litter receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any public place or private premises. 
(Ord. No. 747, § 3, 3-18-85) 
Sec. 14-54. - Littering from vehicles. 
    No person, while the operator of or passenger in a vehicle, shall deposit litter upon any public place or private premises. 
    No person shall drive or move any loaded or partly loaded truck or other vehicle within the city unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any part of its load, contents or litter from being blown or deposited upon any public place or private premises. Nor shall any person drive or move any vehicle or truck within the city, the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any public place or private premises, mud, dirt, sticky substance, litter or foreign matter of any kind. 
    No person hauling earth, trash, slag, concrete, gravel, coke, coal or other substance in any vehicle along or over any of the streets of the city shall allow that earth, trash, slag, concrete, gravel or other substance to escape from any vehicle and be deposited upon any of the streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner, driver or operator of any car, truck, machine or other vehicle which tracks or deposits dirt, mud, vegetation or similar substances onto any paved street in the city to fail to immediately commence removal of any such substance and complete such removal within two hours after such substance was tracked or deposited thereon. 
(Ord. No. 747, § 4, 3-18-85) 
Sec. 14-55. - Litter from construction site. 
    Building materials, construction equipment and other related items may be maintained on public or private property during the normal construction process. 
    Each contractor shall be responsible for the job site so that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any public place or other private premises. 
    Litter or other debris, including dirt and mud, deposited as the result of normal construction process upon any public place or private premises, shall be removed by the contractor. 
(Ord. No. 747, § 5, 3-18-85) 
Sec. 14-56. - Upsetting or tampering with receptacles. 
    No person shall upset or tamper with a public or private receptacle designed or used for the deposit of litter or cause or permit its contents to be deposited or strewn in or upon any public place or private premises. 
(Ord. No. 747, § 6, 3-18-85) 
Sec. 14-57. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $25.00 nor more than $500.00 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 747, § 7, 3-18-85) 
Sec. 14-58. - Garbage and trash collection ordinance. 
    The owners of property, both public and private, shall have the right to place garbage, trash and other litter in authorized litter receptacles in order that the garbage and trash collector may remove the same from the property all in accordance with the terms and provisions of Ordinance Number 374, adopted on June 6, 1977. 
(Ord. No. 747, § 8, 3-18-85) 
Chapter 15 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1]

Sec. 15-1. - Accommodating utilities. 
    The city council hereby formally adopts the State of Alabama Highway Department Standards for Accommodating Utilities on Highway Rights-of-Way as standards (as written and future amendments thereto) for use by the city for accommodating utilities on roads and streets under the jurisdiction of the city which have involved or will involve the expenditure of state or federal highway funds. 
(Ord. No. 225, § 1, 11-1-71) 
Cross reference- Utilities, Ch. 17. 
State Law reference- Railroads and public utilities using streets to keep streets in repair, etc., Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-49-3. 
Sec. 15-2. - Street cutting permit-Establishment of procedure; fee. 
(a)  Applicability. These standards shall apply to all underground public and private utilities that are to be located, adjusted, repaired or relocated within the rights-of-way of roadways under the jurisdiction of the city. It shall be unlawful for any person other than an authorized officer, employee or agent of the city to make any opening, cut or excavation in or under the surface of any street, alley, sidewalk or public way on the property of the city without having first obtained a permit as provided by this section. All permanent pavement repair work is to be performed by the city or a contractor acting on behalf of the city. It is the responsibility of the utility owner or contractor to coordinate with the city engineer on work to be performed. The utility owner or contractor will be responsible for installing proper backfill, compacting appropriately, and installing a temporary asphalt repair once the utility work is complete. Upon inspection by the city, the city or contractor acting on behalf of the city will complete the necessary paving work to repair the surface in a permanent and appropriate manner. 
(b)  Application and fees. 
(1)  Street cut fee. An underlying street cut fee in the amount of $100.00 shall accompany a street cutting permit application for utility work in city right-of-way. 
(2)  Restoration deposit. A restoration deposit is required to accompany a street cutting permit application to pay for the proper restoration of asphalt or concrete that was removed. The city will be responsible for the repair, and the deposit will be used for that purpose. It will be the responsibility of the utility company or contractor making the cut to properly backfill the excavated area per city specifications and details in preparation for the new asphalt and/or new concrete to be installed. 
A sketch that shows the extents and dimensions of the impacted area shall be provided to the city engineer prior to submission of a street cut permit application or, in the case of an emergency situation as identified in section 15-4, upon application for a permit. The city engineer will determine the amount of the restoration deposit per the sketch provided based on current industry costs for construction labor and materials, rounded up to the nearest hundred. The deposit will be filed with the city engineer. 
Any excess of such deposit over the cost required for proper restoration shall remain on deposit with the city for such time as the utility company or contractor is licensed to do business within the city and can be transferred for future restoration deposits. If the cost of restoration exceeds the amount of the deposit, the difference shall be paid by the utility company or contractor. The payment must be paid within five days of the day upon which the applicant is billed by the city for the excess amount. 
(3)  Impact fee for new surface. Additionally, any cut made in pavement, curb or sidewalk which has been constructed or repaved less than five years from the date the permit application and fee are filed is subject to an additional impact fee that will become part of the general fund of the city. The amount of the said impact fee will be prorated according to the age of the pavement as outlined below: 
Impact Fee for New Surfaces (= 5 years): during first 12 months after completion $500.00 during second 12 months after completion  400.00 during third 12 months after completion  300.00 during fourth 12 months after completion  200.00 during fifth 12 months after completion  100.00  
(Ord. No. 2677 , 9-12-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2677 , adopted Sept. 12, 2016, amended § 15-2 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former § 15-2 pertained to street cutting permit-fee; insurance and derived from Ord. No. 97, § 3, adopted Feb. 3, 1964; Ord. No. 290, § 2, adopted Dec. 2, 1974; Ord. No. 1425, adopted Jan. 5, 1994. 
Sec. 15-3. - Same-Performance. 
    Before any contractor shall engage in the business of making excavations in the city, he shall first obtain the proper license and execute and deposit a good and sufficient bond in the sum of $10,000.00 with the city engineer. The bond shall be executed by a corporate surety authorized to do business in the State of Alabama. The bond shall provide that the city shall be indemnified and saved harmless from all claims and liabilities arising from acts or omissions of such person and his employee, servants and agents in performing such work or from any unfaithful or inadequate work done either by him or by his employees, servants and agents, and that all work done by such person shall be performed in a good and workmanlike manner, conforming to the specification requirements herein in addition to all other city regulations and requirements. This bond shall remain in full force and effect until 30 days after receipt by the city engineer of written notice of the surety's intent to cancel this bond. Except with respect to liability accruing prior to the effective date of cancellation, the surety's liability on the bond shall terminate 30 days after receipt by the city engineer of such written notice. The bond shall be submitted to the city engineer for approval and shall be kept in the custody of the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 2677 , 9-12-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2677 , adopted Sept. 12, 2016, amended § 15-3 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former § 15-3 pertained to same-performance bond and derived from Ord. No. 97, § V, adopted Feb. 3, 1964. 
Sec. 15-4. - Same-Emergency repairs. 
    In the event that any sewer, main, conduit or other utility installation in or under any street, alley, sidewalk or public way shall burst, break or otherwise be in such condition as to seriously endanger persons or property, the owner of such sewer, main, conduit or other installation shall immediately repair such trouble and shall immediately take all necessary steps to make such location safe and secure. The city should be notified of any emergency work performed as soon as possible. Such owner shall not begin making any permanent repairs to such street, alley, sidewalk or public way until he meets the permit requirements as provided in this article. Such permit shall be secured within 18 hours after such break or serious trouble shall have developed, and the necessary temporary repairs to the street, alley, sidewalk or public way shall be made as directed by the city engineer or his authorized deputy and shall be completed as soon as practical after receipt of proper permit. 
(Ord. No. 2677 , 9-12-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2677 , adopted Sept. 12, 2016, amended § 15-4 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former § 15-4 pertained to same-repair and derived from Ord. No. 97, § IV, adopted Feb. 3, 1964. 
Sec. 15-5. - Same-Specifications and standards. 
    All work shall conform to the City of Vestavia Hills guidelines for utility repair in public right-of-way. See the City of Vestavia Hills Public Works Manual and the City of Vestavia Hills Subdivision Regulations 
(Ord. No. 2677 , 9-12-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2677 , adopted Sept. 12, 2016, amended § 15-5 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former § 15-5 pertained to blasting permit-fee and derived from Ord. No. 97, § I, adopted Feb. 3, 1964. 
Sec. 15-6. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2677 , adopted Sept. 12, 2016, repealed § 15-6 in its entirety. Former § 15-6 pertained to same-bond; insurance and derived from Ord. No. 97, § II, adopted Feb. 3, 1964. 
Sec. 15-7. - Deposit of construction materials, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in or responsible for the construction of any structure or the grading, clearing or maintaining of any lot within the city limits to cause or permit the depositing of soil, rocks, gravel, mud, cement, construction debris and maintenance debris on the traveled way, gutters, sidewalks or storm draining facilities of any street, alley or thoroughfare of said city at any time. The acts prohibited by this section shall include the scattering of soil, sand, cement and mud by the tires and tracts of construction vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 209, § 1, 7-6-71; Ord. No. 2677 , 9-12-16) 
Sec. 15-8. - Developers of subdivisions to guarantee street improvement and construction. 
    Developers of subdivisions in the city shall execute and deliver a written agreement and comply with the requirements, policies and procedures set forth in the city's Public Works Manual as approved by the city's planning and zoning commission. All subdivisions shall be built in accordance with the minimum requirements set forth in said agreement and in compliance with all other terms and provisions of the Public Works Manual and the Vestavia Hills Subdivision regulations. 
(Ord. No. 751, § 1, 4-15-85; Ord. No. 2677 , 9-12-16) 
Cross reference- Driveways, § 15-11 
Sec. 15-9. - Rocks, stones and other obstructions on roadways prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to place any rocks, stones or other obstruction or cause or permit the same to remain in any part of the paved portion of any dedicated public street, alley or road in the city, including curbs and gutters, abutting any property owned and/or occupied by said person, firm or corporation. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to obstruct the free passage of motor vehicles along the paved portion of any dedicated public street, road or alley in the city, including roadways, curbs and gutters by the placement of rocks, obstructions or other encroachments. 
(c)  Should any person, firm or corporation wish to place any rocks or other encumbrances on any part of the unimproved portion of any dedicated public street, road or alley in the city, then in such event such rocks and other encumbrances shall be placed a minimum distance of one foot from the edge of the improved street, road or alley and in such a manner so as to not interfere or obstruct motor vehicular traffic along the improved portion of said dedicated public street, road or alley. 
(Ord. No. 826, §§ 1-3, 3-17-86) 
Sec. 15-10. - Driveways. 
(a)  Permit required. No person, firm, corporation or other entity shall hereafter construct, build, establish or maintain any driveway over, across or upon any portion of the public sidewalk or public road, street or parkway without first having obtained a written permit to do so from the engineering department of the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama. 
(b)  Application for permit. Application for a permit must be made in writing upon forms furnished by the city. Said application shall contain the name and address of the person, firm, corporation or other entity making the application, the name of the contractor or person who is to construct said driveway and the proposed location and dimensions of such driveway. Complete plans and specifications shall be submitted to the fire department and engineering department at least seven days before the permit shall be issued. 
(c)  Health, safety and general welfare. No permit required by this section shall be issued unless the city engineer finds that the driveway or sidewalk to be constructed under the permit will not unreasonably interfere with vehicular and pedestrian traffic along that street, the demand and necessity for parking spaces on that street and the means of ingress and egress from abutting property and adjacent properties and that the health, welfare and safety of the public will not be unreasonably impaired. 
(d)  Permit fee. Before any work is started, the applicant or the contractor for the applicant shall pay a permit fee of $25.00. 
(e)  Repair and restoration. The applicant will cause the curb, sidewalk and street area affected by construction of the driveway to be restored to a condition equal to the condition thereof prior to the construction; he or she will reimburse the city any costs which it may incur in making good any of the aforesaid agreements which the owner may fail to make good, and the city shall have a lien upon the abutting property for any such costs. 
(f)  Location of driveway. All applications for the construction of driveways shall be accompanied by detailed plans, specifications and drawings showing the proposed location. The drawings shall be approved by the city engineer, the fire department, and the police department before the issuance of a permit for construction of any such driveway. For public safety reasons, the ultimate decision regarding the location of the driveway shall be made by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1811, Art. I, 5-3-00) 
Sec. 15-11. - Access to buildings by fire apparatus. 
(a)  Access. In order to promote the health, safety and general welfare of persons and property in the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama, all buildings shall be accessible to fire apparatus. In no event shall fire apparatus have access within more than a distance of 100 feet from any said building. Stated another way, fire apparatus shall have access within 100 feet of any and all buildings located within the corporate city limits of the City of Vestavia Hills, Alabama. 
(b)  Means of access. If fire apparatus does not have access within 100 feet of a building via a public street or road, then in such event the owner of that building shall construct and install, at owner's sole expense, a bridge, private road or driveway, so that fire apparatus shall have access within 100 feet of said building. 
(c)  Width of access. 
(1)  Residential buildings. Access to residential buildings by fire apparatus shall be 14 feet in width for residential buildings for up to three residences; driveways for more than three residences would have to meet the minor street requirements as set forth by the Vestavia Hills Subdivision Regulations. 
(2)  Commercial buildings. Access to commercial buildings by fire apparatus according to the 1997 Standard Fire Prevention Code shall be 20 feet in width for commercial buildings. 
(d)  Buildings located more than 150 feet off of public right-of-way. 
(1)  Approval. No building shall be constructed or erected more than 150 feet off of the right-of-way without prior approval of access by the fire marshal for the Vestavia Hills Fire Department. 
(2)  Access by fire apparatus. Every building constructed more than 150 feet off of the right-of-way shall be accessible by fire apparatus by way of bridge, roadway or private drive to within 100 feet of said building. This accessibility shall be 20 feet in width for commercial buildings and 14 feet in width for residential buildings with a vertical clearance of 13 feet six inches and shall be constructed of material approved by the city engineer. (See subsection (c) above.) This accessibility shall have an all-weather driving surface with an adequate roadway turning radius capable of supporting the imposed loads of fire apparatus. 
(3)  Grade. The minimum grade for driveways, private roads and bridges shall be not more than 25 percent. 
(4)  Turning radius. Driveways and private roads shall provide a cul-de-sac with a turning radius of 70 degrees or a fire-official-approved alternative. 
(5)  Fire hydrant. Any building located more than 500 feet from the nearest right-of-way that requires an additional fire hydrant shall be installed at the owner's or developer's expense. 
(Ord. No. 1811, Art. II, 5-3-00) 
Chapter 16 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; animals and fowl, Ch. 4; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 8; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 9; utilities, Ch. 17; ordinances not affected by code, § 1-10.
